In case you're wondering why the T1i over the T2i, it was because we had no interest in the new video features on the T2i (which is essentially the only meaningful difference between the T2i and T1i, while everything else is more or less Canon 'hype') and so we opted for the equally highly regarded but less expensive T1i.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Camera!
Reviews.Author: dewey
Reviews.Content: This is truly an amazing camera and a bargain for the money. I was skeptical at first because of the negative ratings. Once I learned how to operate the camera in low light I found that the negative ratings were all wrong! The image stabilizer does an admirable job, even at the 140x limit. It performs all functions well. One must have a little patience at first to experiment with the myriad of functions, but once you get the hang of it you are well on your way to taking some really quality shots. Well worth the money and don't believe the negatives. They haven't taken the time to explore it's functions.

Reviews.Title: Very Good. With Lots of Options
Reviews.Author: Spudman
Reviews.Content: After abandoning plans to make an SLR my next camera, I narrowed by choices to the Pentax X90, the Fuji HS10, Panasonic FZ40, Olympus 800UZ, and the Sony DSC-HX1. Before making my decision I read many many reviews of each camera on the Amazon site and elsewhere. I studied photos taken with the candidates posted here and on Flickr. I visited stores like Best Buy, HH Gregg and others for some hands on looks. Tired of looking and confused by the choices, I finally bought the Canon SX 30, a camera near the top of my list of choices. I was swayed by that promising 35x zoom, the impressive miniature mode movies and stills I'd seen, the 14.1 mega pixels, and mostly by the irresistible $318 Black Friday special price.  Considering what I paid for the Canon, I'm not terribly disappointed. Had I paid closer to its initial $400 + price, I'm sure I wouldn't have been happy with the decision.Details regarding features and specifications are available here and on any good camera site. I'll restrict this review instead to my experience with the Canon SX30is and my impressions after two months and many shutter snaps. The Canon s my fourth mega zoom or bridge camera; it replaced a Panasonic Lumix DMC with an 18x zoom.ERGONOMICS AND CONTROLS  This camera has a learning curve, and I continue to learn as I use the camera. It's not a light camera, mostly requiring two hands to hold it steady especially when fully zoomed. I like that the flash flips up manually though I sometimes forget to lift it. That mega zoom really projects so be careful when taking a picture through a window or taking a close-up shot. I don't find the controls intuitive. Some settings require using the menu button, some the function button, some the display button , and some the four options around the function button. It's easy for a newbee to miss a shot while figuring out what to do. Example: Press the function button to delete one picture. Press the menu button to delete all of the photos. Of course, each button press is followed by others.For 11 dollars from Adorama (on Amazon)one can buy a cheat sheet that summarizes how to access all of the camera's functions. How many cameras need one of these?ZOOM -  The zoom, I suppose, is as advertised though many of the impressive sample shots I saw prepurchase were taken with the digital zoom. Maybe it's zoom greed, but the 35x isn't as impressive as I thought it would be. The 140x fully zoomed in digital is impressive but the clarity of the shots at that length lack clarity as expected. At that length I have much better success using a tripod or some other form of support. To demonstrate my zoom greed, I  purchased a cheap 2.2x teledapter even though Canon advises against it. The heavy accessory screwed on to the adapter fine but the pictures with it were terrible.PICTURE QUALITY -  For me it can be uneven. Many of my keepers have to be tweaked with a photo program. Occasionally I'll end up with a Wow quality picture, even a few rare ones right out of the box. I have least success using the auto mode and better success using the specific settings, especially the P mode. The vivid mode is wonderful and portrait is good. Face detection has been fine for me. In the Scene modes, I like low light, super vivid, snow, color accent and fish-eye effect. I've had lots of fun with the fish-eye effect and taken some very funny pictures with it. Color swap is fun and can produce some awesome results, but for me it's tricky to set up the colors to swap. Color accent can produce some terrific results.ACCESSORIES - Since the camera lens isn't threaded I bought Canon's lens adapter for adding filters. I keep a UV filter on all the time instead of using the lens cap and also have a circular polarizer and the aforementioned 2.2x tele conversion lens. The polarizer works fine but is unnecessary since the vivid setting produces deep blue skies by itself. The camera also has a setting to specifically emphasize specific colors, including blue.Last random thoughts of a Potato HeadThis is my fourth bridge or mega zoom camera. I'm always upgrading to get more zoom or mega pixels. My best camera was a Sony DSC H1 camera with 12x lens three cameras ago that with a dedicated Sony teleconverter almost matched the zoom of this Canon and took better pictures.In auto mode the focus can be fickle and I've missed some good shots because of it.Can't force flash in auto mode, but since I don't use it often....I really like the feature that lets you zoom out and then in again with the press of a button when you've lost your target. Great feature.The articulated LCD screen is no big deal for me. I seldom use the feature and would gladly trade it for a 3" screen. Doesn't seem possible that .3 inches could make such a difference. Quality of picture on the LCD screen is fine, not outstanding.Face detection works well and battery life is good. If charged ahead of time, the battery should through a day of serious picture taking.Colors are mostly accurate. With tweaking of settings using the P setting, I can get good pictures of my two white dogs. Getting good pictures of white animals can be difficult.Haven't used it often, but movie mode is more than acceptable and the dedicated movie button is very convenient. I'm disappointed with the miniature mode films I'm taking but still working on it.The photos that impressed me most are those of a red tailed hawk that was in a large, shadowy cage. Using the low light setting and 35x zoom I got some decent pictures. Somehow the bars of the cage in the foreground disappeared in the pictures that almost look like those of an uncaged bird. Look for them in the posted pictures.Finally - For the same price, I might buy this camera again. The Canon SX30is has so many features that one who can remember how to use all the controls, has a good eye, and is creative can have lots of fun with this camera. Just want a simple point and shoot?  Keep looking.Addendumb 8/12/11 - Ever looking for better photo results, I sold this camera and bought an SLR. Yes, I'm getting pictures that are a little sharper, but I really miss the Canon's zoom and especially the fun of that fish eye option. At times I wish I had kept the Canon.

Reviews.Title: Extra zoom, but without the extra image quality...
Reviews.Author: JReview11
Reviews.Content: After receiving this product and trying it out for a couple of days, I was very disappointed to see a camera that, based on appearance and features, looked to be a fantastic addition to the point and shoot family. Instead, after testing photos (both on auto and manual), I couldn't get a single photo to impress me unless it was shot in macro! Noise on most images was inexcusably noticeable, regardless of the ISO (or other) settings I tried. When there wasn't a lot of noise, there was instead so much chromatic aberration in lighter environments that I just couldn't stand it. Overall sharpness on any image taken was poor (except for macro once again). This was still the same even when changing the picture resolution from 14mp to 7mp (one megapixel less than the camera I was trying to replace).I had held off buying the SX20 at first (which, in general, had nice reviews) for literally months because I was thinking they'd have a good successor. At first, from specs, it sure looked like it. The zoom really is great (not to mention convenient). The features and settings are easy to use and very customizable. Yet, for ~$400, the image quality was such a letdown (even for a point and shoot camera) that it wasn't worth the cost to me. The camera I had been using from a few years back (also a Canon) took much sharper photos (manual or auto). This is what prompted me to return the SX30 as soon as possible. That bothered me too much.After doing so, I looked into some alternatives and decided on Nikon's P100 model. Reviews looked promising, and overall it had some nice specs too, so I thought I might as well try it out. After testing its settings on dozens of pictures, I've decided I should have bought this from the start. Chromatic aberration is nearly non-existent (which is perhaps the biggest improvement over the SX30). Noise only gets really noticeable at higher ISO's (which isn't surprising). It shoots 1080p instead of 720p video (which is sweet). Pictures come out quite nice on auto (and, it too has very good features that are customizable). Very nice overall, and it's light. One thing I should mention though is that, by default, the P100 had the image quality set to "Normal", rather than "Fine". I quickly made the switch to "Fine" after discovering this, and have since enjoyed taking pictures with it.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: Linda J. Liljehorn "Linda Liljehorn swing dance"
Reviews.Content: This is an awesome camera!  The zoom is phenomenal.  I got a great shot of my husband water skiing.  It froze the image (and for being in a rocking boat, that is a feat in itself). It showed the water cutting his ski and flying up behind him in great detail.  It is reasonably light weight and the batteries last a long time.  I like the various "scene" options like low light etc.  I was able to get a detailed shot of the moon one night.  It looks like it came out of a textbook.  The flash seems to be powerful enough and it even has a setting where you can boost the flash if you need to. This is the first camera I've had that takes decent indoor shots.  Usually, I take more outdoor shots than indoors.  I bought the camera so I could have the zoom to get great nature shots.  I have NOT been disappointed.  It is reasonably priced for this type of camera.  I like that it isn't as complicated as an SLR, but you can also manually set it if you want to.  I found that the auto setting isn't always the best, but finding the best setting is just a matter of getting used to using it and experimenting.  The image stabilizer in this camera is nothing short of outstanding.  If you are looking for great pictures, with not much work, this is the camera.  I can't think of one thing I don't like about it.

Reviews.Title: GREAT
Reviews.Content: This is by far the best camera I've owned and getting away from SLR has been wonderful. The camera takes great still's I can get shots of the craters on the moon and honey bee's in flight. The HD movies are fantastic 15min with a 2gig card and although the users manual is lengthy with a couple of filters just go out and play with it. 1000+ shots on a 2gig card, I'ld suggest an extra battery. but 300 shots is easy out of one.

Reviews.Title: Great point and shoot and great telephoto lens
Reviews.Author: Robert E. Fuller
Reviews.Content: For some situations there is no substitute for being able to zoom in close. That is where this camera shines! I captured a great photo of a friend because I could zoom in. She was on the beach capturing photos of huge waves. I captured her and the wave. She loved the shot so much she made it here i.d. photo on Facebook.The image stabilization is the ideal complement to the zoom. I never thought I would be able to, but I can hand-hold at full zoom and get a sharp picture.I put a 6 gb card in it and have all the capacity I need. I can shoot an hour and a half of video. I can freely use the continuous photo feature to capture the peak of wave splash and discard the ones I don't want.Another feature I am liking is one which reduces contrast. It is hard to get a shot of beach, ocean and clouds that does justice to all three elements. HDR does not work well in that circumstance, because I can't get the wave to hold still! But I get some really nice shots when the camera lightens the dark spots and darkens the light spots a bit. Now I can bracket exposures, finish the contrast improvement in software and have a beautiful picture.Ok, so I am not making three-foot posters and the image would probably be very grainy if I did. There must be some distortion in the corners, too. But for $400 I am getting a lot of fine photos for my purposes and I did not spend $6k for a lens that will not get as close...better quality, yes, but not as highly magnified.I tried the Nikon P100 first and returned it. This one is a keeper.I sometimes hit the button to reduce the zoom temporarily when I do not want to, but I am learning to avoid that. I wish I could remove the memory card without taking the quick-connect adapter off the bottom of the camera. I could also use something to remind me to take the camera along when I am walking out the door :-).

Reviews.Title: Best camera I ever owned
Reviews.Author: k2
Reviews.Content: I needed a new camera and did quite a bit of research to find out what is new in the camera world.  It was a little challenging.  But this Canon model kept coming up and the more I looked into it, the more I liked what I saw.  When I actually got the camera in my hands, I was very pleased with the number of features it has and the quality of the pictures.  I am not a big camera buff but I do like quality.  This camera gives you just enough manual adjustment to make it fun and enough point and shoot simplicity to make it easy to operate.  Some of the features are so fun to use because they are unusual (I haven't had a new camera for about 6 years).  I really love this camera.  Hope you do too.The 35x zoom is also a really great feature.  I had read other reviews before I purchased this camera.  I found that more professional photographers were not pleased with the speed of certain functions on the camera.  For the rest of us, who cares---this camera is fun.  Go for it. ps.  don't forget to buy a memory chip (the camera doesn't have memory) and an extra battery is not a bad idea either.  I found a good one on amazon.

Reviews.Title: a bit disappointed
Reviews.Author: jg
Reviews.Content: Had it for a month now, and it's not meeting my expectations. I have a compact P&S; Canon SD 960, and it takes unbelievably sharp picures. I then wanted a camera with a powerful zoom, high macro ability and thought the SX30 was the right choice. But as I've seen in a number of reviews now, the sharpness is not there, and I can't understand it. How can a camera with that lens take pictures less sharp than my mini P&S;???  Another issue for me is that it seems to take a long time to be ready to take the next shot after shooting. Seems like 3,4,5 seconds?  Don't get me wrong, it's not a complete dog, there are some nice features, the pictures are pretty good, the zoom is exceptional, but I expected greatness after my great experience with the small compact  Now when I take pictures, I use my small P&S; for non-zoomed pix, and the SX30 when a zoom is appropriate.  But that is certainly not what I had in mind when I spent my $500 (camera,memory card, warrranty)

Reviews.Title: Canon
Reviews.Author: SportsDoc
Reviews.Content: Very well finished product. Images are not as sharp as I would have expected from an expensive Canon camera.I had hoped that the picture quality would rival those that I take with my Canon SLR with Canon zoom lens. The autofocus is quick, but the focus is not sharp. The Zoom function sometimes seems to "lock up" which is quite surprising.Overall a little disappointing, I expected better performance based on my experience with my small Canon S450"point and shoot". Given the little difference in size I think I'm better off using my Canon Rebel with zoom!

Reviews.Title: Awesome stabilization - very poor color consistency
Reviews.Author: Tom Niemeier
Reviews.Content: I bought at $429 and got one of the first. I gave 5 stars when I first did a review, but the inability to produce true color is frustrating. While filming the color tint will change, and photos have the same problem. Focusing can be challenging sometimes.What's awesome is its ability to take a clear shot at even the 140x zoom. Even terrific portrait shots from 50 feet away. Great shots for identifying birds. The main reason for buying was the zoom and we're having a BLAST using it. Since we're mainly snapshot people, this makes it worth the money. We get to skip the bulky lens, frame our pic exactly, and save a ton of money. I can work around the color shifts.There are a lot of great thoughts put into this camera. The color tints and the lens retracting on its own are my only complaints. I wish the lens would simply stay wherever I set it - aggravating when waiting for wildlife shots.Also bought B&W; lenses - UV and polarizer. But I find the polarized lens difficult to use with the auto functions. I would not spend that kind of money for lenses again. Amazon didn't have the adapter, so sourced it elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: Ups and Downs of the Canon SX30
Reviews.Author: Reuben C.
Reviews.Content: I didn't order my Canon SX30 off of Amazon but got it from Best Buy, instead. It is a worthy successor to my old Canon PowerShot SD880 IS Digital ELPH. I have my share of PROS and CONS for the camera in my arsenal of photography equipment.CONS:One of the few problems with the camera is its speed. You try to get a picture of your friends playing basketball or soccer, you'll likely end up with a blurry image and/or not catching your friend scoring at the last second on time. Unlike my Canon EOS Digital Rebel XT which is faster in taking snapshots despite it's an old Canon model, the Canon SX30 isn't that great in action. You need to have patience to take an action shot with it. My suggestion is to take a video of the action if you still have trouble with the action snapshots.Be careful how you use the long-range zoom. Sure, it is sweet of Canon to give this camera this zoom but you may have to deal with it going out of focus. The best range I used without losing focus was at over 200 mm. Plus, the red color may come out all pixelated at your selected long range. If you want to get a better shot ranging at a distance with focus, get a tripod.If you're a fan of taking self-portraits using a mirror while in a low-light room, your picture may come out grainy. Even with the manual flash engaged, you may get the same results. Try increasing the exposure to increase lighting in your picture.A little issue is having to get used to setting the manual flash on. Yes, you need to open the flash on your own. It doesn't open automatically unlike most other cameras. Plus, everytime you take a picture in a low-light location, there's a small chance you will get an indicator on your camera to use the flash. Press the flash button to make it do a flash.Customizing your schemes on 'C1' and 'C2' is a pain. Unlike my older Canon that does allow to keep the custom changes, this camera doesn't seem to keep them. Everytime you turn it off and swtich it back on later, the two customade sections reset every time. I have yet to find a solution to that frustrating issue.Lastly, the camera is somewhat bulky and its size is almost equal to a regular DSLR camera. One time I got a camera bag made by Lowepro, I was unable to fit my camera in. A different camera bag I got for it is a Targus. Find a good size bag from them or another company before making your purchase.PROS:The HD video at 720 delivers good quality visual recordings. Go ahead and make a video of it as long as you want. What's also good is that your recordings won't catch any un-wanted background noise whenever you put your fingers on the zoom or stop the recordings. My old Canon SD880 had a problem getting that noise everytime I record; but, not this camera!One of the features I like the most is the swivel screen. You can either switch the screen to the back or front. There's also moving the screen to face you for a better self-portrait or with a friend. On older cameras, you have to try a number of times if the picture came out right or not. And, it's better not to have the swivel screen open more often. Keep the screen facing the camera and closed everytime you're done.Do you perfer taking pictures using the old method? This camera can do that! Just press the 'DISP' twice to switch from the screen to the viewfinder. It's a little slow in the viewfinder but you want it at that setting, then go for it.Even uploading your media from the camera to your computer is fast enough. You need to have a USB camera connector, by the way.Conclusion:That's about it; and, there is a lot more to learn about the Canon SX30. Think of good strategies for your camera and be creative of your photography. Enjoy and keep it in good shape!

Reviews.Title: As Good As it Gets
Reviews.Author: Robert L. Reynolds "Bob Reynolds"
Reviews.Content: This 4 star review should probably be a 4.5 star.  After 5 years good experience with Canon S3 IS, this camera is a vast upgrade.  I would recommend buying this model if you are just a hobby photographer such as myself since it is probably as good as it gets for a point and shoot camera.THE GOOD:  35x optical zoom and 140x with digital....I'm in heaven!  Great quality lens in any event.  2.7 inch LCD is adequate considering that it swivels for a big plus.  Would have liked a 3 inch or larger.  Retaining the optical viewer is great.  Image stabilization is much improved to the point where taking a handheld picture at 140x outdoors is no real challenge.  Using 140x in low light indoors is possible but takes a little effort.  Zoom assist button is real nice addition.  All the face recognition software and features is another plus, but, will probably not be used by me.  General layout of buttons, wheels, and knobs, and menus is probably about as good as it gets for this complicated camera and makes holding the camera more comfortable than old S3.  I even like the smaller, lighter battery that lasts longer than 4 AAs and I was able to buy a spare for less cost than 4 rechargeable AAs.  The location of memory card in same compartment with battery is a "don't care".  The video is good. If I wanted perfect video I would get a camcorder.  The ease of taking video, jumping into manual mode, setting ISO, and going automatically into macro if needed are all nice features.LESS GOOD:  Several of the negative reviews I have seen could be handled by reading the 196 page user guide which is part of the furnished CD.  No printed copy is furnished, but who, besides me, would actually read it anyhow?  I printed 98 pages of the best material to supplement my 5 years experience with very similar S3.  I have never skimmed the guide or picked up this new camera without learning something new.  I am getting better and better results with each day since this camera takes some work to get maximum results.  The external lens interface has what looks like internal threads but is actually just ridges to retain the lens cap.  The external part has some sort of flange where an adapter can be attached for filter use. Why not just accept filters directly?PERSONAL OBSERVATIONS:  The picture quality is not just automatically great.  Proper settings help a lot, but may require a little study in the 196 page guide. Outdoors at 140x a great deal depends on the subject.  If focused on area that has nearer and further away material then focus is confused and the picture is fuzzy. An object at set distance comes out good. You can use manual focus, but it takes some effort.  Indoors it is difficult to focus using 140x in low light, and once done, it is almost essential to use the flash for faster shutter speed and crisp picture.  Upon suggestion of another reviewer I am using the P mode shooting and setting the ISO to limit at 400.  This seems to help.

Reviews.Title: A surprising value in a "do-it-all" package
Reviews.Author: John Boyers "FoneJunkie"
Reviews.Content: The old saying that "the best camera you have is the one you have with you" is true, and especially so with this handy little jewel.A fantastic feature-packed value for the money.I've used the camera for a couple of weeks, under various conditions, both video and still and it amazes, every time. The "pros" I've listed sound like a bunch of ad copy, buteach point was a surprise to discover, and a good one, for sure.Pros:Battery life is excellent, even with lots of playback, off/on cycles and zooming.The wide range of settings in "menu" allows appropriate control under every conceivable condition.The convenience of having separate buttons for stills and video makes going between the two modes instant and very handy.The 35X zoom reaches out and gets the image, whether still or video, every time. The focus locks on and stays on, even in low light.Under rough conditions, the swing out viewing screen nests facing inward, so with the lens cap on, the camera is really well protected from dirt or damage during transport.Two easily programmed custom setups allow for individual shooting situations and are conveniently activated with a twist of the top knob.The menu and wheel control are not only easy to get at, but they also make sense. Going where  you need to go and making the adjustment you want is quick and convenient.The manual settings are also easy to use, as you can toggle between f stop and shutter speed with one button push. Getting a sunrise or sunset to darken down for max chroma is fast and accurate.The stabilization system is surprisingly effective. Blur from camera movement is infrequent and minimal, only really an issue in very low light where no camera would do much better.The image stabilization is even more amazing in video mode- you might think the camera is on a tripod with a fluid head, but it's just a well designed IS, that's it, plain and simple.Cons: Opening the flash requires flipping it up by the front, not pushing a well-placed button.Manual focus is a bit unhandy. Over and undershooting with the control is an issue. When appropriate, let the auto focus do its job. It will.The eye level viewfinder is a bit lacking in detail. It's difficult to see good sharp focus because of the lack of detail in the finder, but autofocus is so accurately, I trust it and have rarely been disappointed.The camera is small, so if you have really big hands and fingers, you might have trouble at first with some of the controls which are close together.The ubiquitous Canon wheel control requires a bit of learning, as it can easily be pushed in by accident while trying to turn it, but this issue goes away with very little practice.Wind noise in the dual mics is a problem, even with the low frequency filter turned on, but none of the consumer cameras would probably do any better.You shouldn't expect it, but the lack of a mic input jack is also something you'd think they'd include but don't, same with most others.Overall opinion: I really believe anyone who purchases this camera will find it a constant and valuable companion that, with a little care, will give years of satisfaction.

Reviews.Title: Great camera, tad pricy
Reviews.Author: J. Murdock "Web editor, wedding photographer"
Reviews.Content: I've had all sorts of cameras from Canon, and this is one of my favorites. Sharp lens, good IS. I don't like the the way they changed the body style from the SX10/SX20 -- this feels harder to hold. Not bad by any means, but I'm less sure with it.One seemingly silly feature that actually works: the digital teleconverter. I've got it set to activate with the "print" button, and it turns the 840mm lens to a 1784mm lens.Now I've had nothing but bad photos from digital zooms in the past -- too much loss of image quality. But on this camera, when you need that kind of reach, it works great. From up on a hill, I was able to shoot a museum just under two miles away and be able to tell what a family of four was wearing as they approached the front doors.But at this price, you're almost better off getting an DSLR and start working toward a full camera system. If you can get it on sale for sub-$350, it's a better deal.

Reviews.Title: Good camera
Reviews.Author: Debasmit
Reviews.Content: Some people really had HUGE problems with my last review as I had asked a question to Amazon buyers instead of writing an actual review.Well,I am sorry about that...and here is an actual review:Pros:Excellent image stabilization: this is very very helpful when you are trying to take a photo while zooming35x zooooooomCustom settings: I love them.You have the option of modifying pretty much everythingManual FocusExcellent buildPretty good gripHD videoExcellent display - photos look much better on the display than my crappy laptopPrice - got it for $399Pretty awesome software: The software in the camera and its integration with the hardware(lens,sensors,etc) is very powerful.I love the SCN mode.There are some pretty cool options in the software that give some neat effect on the photos, like color accent,etc.Cons:Couldn't find too many,but here are some -Low light image quality (Max ISO 1600)I couldn't change the focal length in manual focus below 20cm or so. Found it a little frustrating to focus on objects in macro setting, and hence was trying the MF, but may be I am doing something wrong.Overall,I would say its a nasty beast out there, if you can tame it.I don't know what the bad reviews are for.It takes pretty decent pictures and the rest is on you.I had a canon before,so getting used to the settings quickly wasn't too much of an issue.UPDATE: Ok. I figured out the issue with the focus. It seems that the camera has issues focusing when I am zooming in macro focus mode.Ideally,I should have been able to hold the camera about a feet away from the object and then zoom into the object and focus on it in macro mode. But actually,you need to hold the camera very very close (1cm-2cm) from the object to shoot it. It is ridiculous when you want to shoot bees/insects, you scare them away!

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: John Hopkins "liveoakranch"
Reviews.Content: The optical zoom and lens quality makes it possible to photo animals at 100 yards. I tested this camera against others in this price range and the Canon SX30IS took clearer, crisper pictures of objects at 100 yards.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera for the money!
Reviews.Author: D. C. Elliot
Reviews.Content: Bought the Canon SX30IS as an upgrade to my point'n'shoot before embarking on our 2-week African safari, knowing I'd want to take close up pics of the wild animals.  The camera FAR exceeded expectations, giving me INCREDIBLE images that rivaled the DSLR's my fellow safari-ites were lugging around. Very easy to use, as well, after reading the simple-to-understand instructions. For game shots, I primarily used the "sports" setting, which allow multiple shots at rapid shutter speeds for capturing moving animals while preserving the high-quality image. Also employed "low light" setting (under "SCN" ["scene"] mode) at twilight and dawn which allowed amazingly bright images without needing flash.  The video came in handy, as well (got some incredible movies of lions and ostriches mating. Not together, you sicko!), although zooming in with the video requires good stabilization, such as a tripod.Battery life is excellent, as well. Bought a spare battery as a reserve, and each charge lasted around 350 or so pics, plus a few minutes of video.  16gig memory card - 4000 + images & movie capacity.Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the price, chose this over rebel t4,t3i,EOS 60D
Reviews.Author: D. Mekonnen "Dan"
Reviews.Content: I don't normally write reviews, but I am compelled to do so for this one.It would be an understatement to say  that this camera is great for the price.I gave it 4 stars for the low-light far distance performance.If you are a family guy who just want to take videos and pictures and don't want the hassle of carrying a large bag, this is a perfect choice.I investigated 4 Canon models: this one and 3 Canon SLR cameras: EOS 60D, Rebel T3 and T3i. I quickly dropped 60D due to its weight. When you add a large zoom lens comparable to 30IS, it becomes very heavy. I left this for professional photographers. Then I liked T3i. Bought one and experimented with it. Takes great pictures. But hard to take any decent video. Then, I scaled down to T3, primary due to price. Still great pictures, but cannot see taking video with it.The SX30IS became the winner, not just due to the price, but the functionality.1) Great pictures at very good light. Quality is not distinguishable from the SLR's when viewed using a large screen TV.2) Great video. You can zoom. It does auto focus. The SLR cannot do that, you will need  a tripod to stabilize the picture. You have to zoom manually by turning the lens. I decided that these SLR cameras are just for taking great pictures and would need to have an additional video camera. 30IS does both for me.3) SX30IS has a nice dial pad to view pictures on TV. This is a very handy feature missing the SLR cameras4) Swivel LCD display is extremely handy during some occasions, especially for taking video at a party. The pricier T3i has that feature.5) Great zoom. Can take a nice closeup picture of my kids playing soccer. Amazing pictures of animals from distant without disturbing them.  For SLRs, you probably need to carry 2 lenses and keep switching b/n the 2, which is extremely awkward at moments you want to take pictures. Took amazing pictures and video of firework on July 4th with SX30IS..On the down side, bad pictures at low light levels at far distance. The SLRs bit it hands down. However, at those situations, red-eyes happen to be a problem, making the pictures difficult to use. Those red eyes are difficult to remove or mitigate without extensive editing.SX30IS Camera works great at close distance even at low light levels. However, you need to use custom setting, not auto setting or the night portrait setting. I ended up defining a night setting (ISO 400 work great) and saved it as one of the camera modes (C1 or C2). This is another great feature.Since the only problem is far-distance low light levels,  I returned all the SLRs and now keeping the SX30IS. Just the perfect one for my family. If it fails to get a good picture when my sons perform at a stage, I will sure be disappointed. Fore everything else, it ill be a great one.The perfect camera would be this with a large sensor. But, Canon won't do that as that would cannibalize the SLR's.

Reviews.Title: Not a good upgrade
Reviews.Author: R Hogan
Reviews.Content: I am going to make this short as it looks like alot of people have gave this good ratings.If you have a Canon SX20 and are upgrading to the SX30 its a disappointing one.The super zoom function works real well as does video,But taking still shots is a challenge with the SX30,Maybe I got a bad one I don't know,But they can only squeeze so many things into a camera with this size sensor and expect high quality pictures across the board.Some nice functions and Great battery life but I am sending mine back..Sorry Canon but this is not a upgrade.

Reviews.Title: The 35X in a point in shoot amazing!
Reviews.Author: David Duncan "Aka Labman"
Reviews.Content: I love the zoom capability! I have had a Canon 20D and a 40D the a G10 I have been trying to go back too point in shoots. simply because I am tired of dealing with all the equipment. I am trying to find my perfect camera. this is close so far. having 24mm-840mm in one lens is amazing. still playing with the camera but so far. I will really test this camera at Rock on the rangepro's* poor mans bird watching camera.* like the flexible view screen great for shooting video/shots over your head*love 24mm-840mm + 14.1 mp for more cropping think about it. HDMI out*separate buttons for video and photo. I can even take a still shot while taking a video. or instantly switch from taking photo to video. Awesome*over all the all photo's and video come out very nice.*fun internal modes like miniature.*simple to usecons*No Raw format*would like faster shutter speed for shooting sports*can't as a shutter release again this was a big disappointment. my G10 allowed for that. these days seems all camera should have a Bluetooth shutter release we can  use via smart phone.* The Sensor I would have been willing to pay more money for a better sensor. The Sensor is more important then the larger Megapixels

Reviews.Title: You paid for what you get....
Reviews.Author: iLikeAmazon
Reviews.Content: I have owned Canon SX1is and Canon SX20is. Just sold my SX20is at eBay and looking for another camera now. I must say the Canon SX1is has better picture than SX20is. But both are not better than my cheap Samsung Digimax i6. However, I paid for what I get. The i6 has weak flash and small zoom. The SX20is has long zoom and good flash. It depends on what you want to do with your camera and how much you can afford. With the custom mode on SX20is, I can get good picture that almost match my i6 camera.Many people complaint about picture quality on SX20is or SX30is. I wonder how Canon can sell their high end models if they make these feature rich zoom monster with same picture quality.I know your answer.So I believe Canon purposely put a lower quality sensor into these mid-range camera and the selling points are the other features, like long zoom, auto mode, etc, etc.So if you can afford $1000 or high, go for the high end camera and you get the best pictures and the feature that you need. A 840mm zoom lens can cost a lot of money !!!If you want a camera with long zoom but can't spend the money, then get this lower end camera.If you just want a nice picture, I believe many lower end camera can take better picture than SX20is or SX30is.When you show any picture in a 7" LCD picture display, most picture from most cameras look nice on it (as long as you don't do side by side comparison from other camera). This is why most picture posted at Amazon site here are nice because Amazon reduced the big picture to small size so you don't see those "defect". But if you need to print large photo (or zoom in your computer screen to 2x or 3x the size) and still want to be very nice on it, then you should buy the high end camera. It is as simple as that.For me, I find it more "fun" to have a long zoom camera with a low budget and as long as I stay with "custom" mode, the picture is OK. My son plays soccer so I need a LONG zoom range to catch him in the field :-)I also tried the Fujifilm HS10 with 30x zoom. Its picture is actually better than SX20is (with some adjustment) !! It is not the best, but better. I also like its manual zoom lens. However, it is just a little too big for me to carry. Also manual zoom lens make it harder to take smooth video with many zoom. But HS10 has the color adjustment for each major color, so you can get the real color for your picture. It is in the same price range as SX20is and SX30is too.Most compact super zoom cameras do not have hot shoes. But HS10 and these Canon SX cameras are two of them with hot shoes. The external flash helps a lot to take group picture indoor and outdoor.Just noticed that Amazon dropped $10 dollars on this camera ! From $399 to $389. I think it will drop more before X'max!! $350 is coming ?11/4/2010: Humm, the price is back to $399 now... I wonder.Here is the setting I use on my Canon SX20is. I am not a profession, try at your own risk :-)- Mode: Custom  <-- auto mode is not great for me....- ISO: 50  <-- I hate noise so I set it to 50 and use external flash.- White Balance: Cloudy  <-- this gives you better color.- Color: Vivid  <-- this gives a little more color.- Brightness: Center Weight Avg.- AF Frame: FlexiZone- AF-Point Zoom: Off- Servo AF: Off- Continuous AF: Off- AF-assist beam: On- MF-Point Zoom: On- Safety MF: On- I-Contrast: Off- Spot AF Point: Center- IS Mode: Shoot OnlyI also posted a review for HS10 at Amazon. Again, read at your own risk :-)

Reviews.Title: Fantastic right out of the box
Reviews.Author: jokebroker
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera as a gift for my wife.  We charged the battery and were sitting on our deck just 3 hours after she opened her gift.  All of a sudden a deer ran down our neighbors yard.  It stopped about 80 - 100 yards away like it wanted to have its photo taken.  My wife took several photos and when we went inside we noticed the deer was in fact a fawn.  What a zoom and great quality camera.

Reviews.Title: Amazing SuperZoom
Reviews.Author: mottophoto
Reviews.Content: I am photo enthusiast and I also own EOS 50D and several L lenses.  I was looking to complement my gear with light super zoom camera that I can use for travel and walk around.  My friend suggested me to get SX30IS.  He used to own SX20IS and after SX30IS came out he bought it too.  After side by side comparison he decided to keep SX30IS and sold his SX20IS.  I bought my SX30IS six month ago and I am extremely happy with it.  For very special occasions I do usually bring my heavy but excellent DSLR gear however for everything else (which is 80% of situations) I have SX30IS with me and it never let me down.  This is unbelievable how this relatively (to DSLR) small camera with (35mm equivalent) 24-840mm zoom could deliver such high quality images.  For those of you who are new to photography I will suggest to spend some time to learn how to use this camera so you can take advantage of all the capabilities of this incredible superzoom.

Reviews.Title: Really good camera!
Reviews.Author: Daniel Treto "dmtspaces"
Reviews.Content: This is the camera you want to get if you want to take great pictures but don't want to spend the money on a DSLR...I have a couple of DSLR's and some point-and-shoots so I'm pretty familiar with cameras...I even still have SLR film cameras!  Anyway, I bought this camera for the wife because someone gave her some pictures they took with an SX10IS, very sharp pictures for a point-and-shoot.  When I received it, I tested it out and boy, does this camera deliver!  I can take perfect pictures with the digital zoom all the way (of course you need a tripod but what camera doesn't at 35x optical x 4 digital zoom distance)...it is by far the best zoom lens I have ever used that was this small...usually, to get that much zoom, you need an almost professional level lens which is so heavy, you need to put the lens on the tripod, not the camera.  The video is amazing...we have watched the videos on our 60" 1080p TV and although the video is only 720p, you can't tell...The best part is the potraits you can take with this camera...they look so professional.  My wife loves the camera and we consider the best camera SHE has ever owned (I use DSLR's mostly).  I do find myself using this camera when I don't want to lug around heavy equipment.  It also comes with a decent flash (lit up my whole living room in the dark, nobody believes I took it in the dark) and I can use my professional flash using the hot-shoe for even better flash options!  This camera has exceeded my expectations exponentially!  Another great feature, I can use my 52mm filters!  I have a UV haze on there for better pictures and for protection and I mount the other filters on top of that one...I can't go out as wide if I use the circular polarizer but otherwise, it's a great feature to have on a so-called point-and-shoot...me and my family are very satisfied and recommend this to anyone who is not looking to invest heavily on a DSLR but want to get that kind of quality...

Reviews.Title: Quinn
Reviews.Author: quinn
Reviews.Content: I have never had a camera of this quality before!! I think this thing is awesome!!! I wish it had a better manual with it though. The Canon has an easy start up guide with it. It is very easy to set up. In the guide it says that Eye-Fi Sd cards might not work. My Eye-Fi card is working just fine and transfers all my pictures to my computer. The camera is easy to hold and press the shutter button at the same time. I love this camera!!

Reviews.Title: Love, Love, LOVE It!
Reviews.Author: Kelly Albrecht "bunneegirl"
Reviews.Content: We were worried about the handful of negative reviews here, but did much research and bought this camera anyway. We are VERY happy we did. I don't know why some reviewers had problems with poor quality photos... we have taken hundreds of gorgeous shots with this camera. Near and far, all lights, indoors and out, flash and not, super high zoom, etc. Beautiful, beautiful pictures. We originally got a Sony Handicam (the lower end model, $250) to shoot family videos. We were so disappointed in the quality of the video we decided to trade up to something that would take great video AND photos. After much research we decided on the Canon SX30IS, and we LOVE it. LOVE LOVE LOVE it. The video quality is far superior to the Handicam we returned, and the photos are fantastic. If we have any problems though, I will post a follow-up.

Reviews.Title: My SX10IS was better.
Reviews.Author: J. Nachison "long-time SF and history lover"
Reviews.Content: I was very disappointed - this camera is not up to the standard set by the SX10IS.  The pictures too grainy at long telephoto (500-840mm) and shutter works slow on normal (HH) people shots.  There is a noticeable delay from when you shoot to when it snaps pic.  Oh well.  i'll do better research on a replacement.

Reviews.Title: To those who don't like the sx30
Reviews.Author: matagordas
Reviews.Content: To those folks that are not taking a little time to understand the basics of using this camera. To the guy that took almost over 100 pics and they were no good...hold down the shutter button half way to focus it. To the guy that had issues with the zoom running in and out all the time..take your finger off the button that does that, it is a great feature. To the people that compare it to a DSLR..it is not one, that is why your wallet is not thinner.I played around with the camera after charging the battery, got some very good shots. Later that night I reviewed the owners mannual and picked up on some features I really like. I'm still learning and it is great for birding I can asure you of that.It is a very good camera for the price.User friendly.You can handhold the camera at 35x and get good shots is reasonably good light.The little flash works like a little flash, pretty good.I'm getting some very good nature shots, mostly in Av and P mode.

Reviews.Title: LOVE it!
Reviews.Author: L Moran
Reviews.Content: I received this camera recently for my 25th birthday and I absolutely LOVE it! I'm an amateur photographer, so I'm still learning how to manually manipulate the settings, but from the few pictures I took the quality is fantastic. Key to this camera is to stay off the Auto setting!!! Take a minute and learn how to balance out the aperture, shutter speed and ISO and you'll be thrilled with the results. I haven't tried the video yet, but I've seen pretty great quality "movies" on YouTube.com with this camera. My only complaint is that the user guide on CD-ROM, but hey, you can't have everything!

Reviews.Title: very good at both
Reviews.Author: sydney
Reviews.Content: This camera is perfect for the family guy who wants high quality images and videos. I have had no problems with the auto setting. In fact, I think everything auto looks great. The key is to let the camera auto focus for a second before snapping the pic. I am very familiar with cameras and have also used most all the other settings on this one. And they are also very cool. But you can just point and shoot also. Keep in mind the jack of all trades is a master of none. So do not think this thing is a 4000 dollar camera meant to take magazine pics. Also don't think this is a sony handy cam for video. But the fact this thing does both very well is a huge bonus, not to mention the zoom!!! I took pics of the moon and you can see all the creators, sooo cool. I would give pic quality a 3.9 and the movie quality a 4.5 in high light and a 3 in very low light. Overall I am very pleased with this unit under 400 bucks so don't think twice about it.

Reviews.Title: Fun and Worthy to Buy!
Reviews.Author: STSL
Reviews.Content: I've been searching around for a P&S; camera for my wife and came across this. Was deciding between this and another couple of models from Olympus and Fujifilm but settled down for this in the end after doing much research. Mainly for the rich features. It is a great buy that i will never regret! My wife and myself simply love it.A versatile multi function cam that is very well worth the price. The powerful 35x optical zoom is especially useful for concerts, shows and performances. It provides unlimited fun for observing the skies and shooting wildlife too. It would cost a lot more if you were to buy a DSLR and the lens required to do this kind of zoom.Picture and video quality are fantastic. The stabilizer works very well even if you zoom all the way to 140x (with 4x digital zoom that comes with the camera). The auto focus should be good enough for normal shots. But using the manual settings will give you surprisingly great quality results for your pictures and special shots. Use it together with a filter adapter and some lens, it will make you feel like a pro!Of course, you can't compare this to a pro DSLR which also cost many times more than this. But for an average to semi-pro shooter, the value of it goes far beyond the price tag that comes with it. I would highly recommend this!

Reviews.Title: Canon SX30 IS
Reviews.Author: Baker
Reviews.Content: Good camera for a point and shoot enthusiast that wants more range and more control of camera settings i.e., ISO, shooting modes, etc.  Do not use the AUTO mode without expecting disappointment as it may set the ISO too high to get quality pictures.  Use the "P" mode and set ISO on Auto the appropriate setting for the lighting and you will get acceptable prints.  Do not expect DSLR picture quality.  This is a very good camera for average picture settings.  It is light weight and easy to use.  It pays to read the on-disk manual and become familiar with the various camera setting options.  This is a fun camera to experiment with.  Best results will be obtained in well lit settings.  Camera registers shots rather slowly even with a fast SDHC class 10 card.  Movie setting has not been tested.  As with most zoom lens, the best quality is not found at either the shortest or longest end of the zoom range. This camera may disappoint a pro enthusiast accustomed to DSLR photo quality but most amatuer or beginning photographers will like it a lot.  Extended zoom range is a little over rated.

Reviews.Title: Exactly what i was looking for
Reviews.Author: Eric J. Koenig
Reviews.Content: I am an amateur photographer who is just beginning to branch into some professional work.  This camera has far exceeded my expectations.  I am just learning the controls, but the pictures are crisp and the zoom is incredible.  The shutter speed is very fast and i have been impressed with the automatic mode so far.  One of the only drawbacks i have seen is that it does feel heavy in my hand, after having light Fuji film cameras. If you are looking for a good quality point and shoot camera that has many pro features, this might be the camera for you.

Reviews.Title: Amateur photographer's opinion...great camera!
Reviews.Author: nycmom
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to take pictures at my son's middle school football games. We're always sitting or standing far from the action on the field, but with this camera I can get amazing closeup shots. I'm even able to capture the expression on his face during plays (ok, so I don't really follow the game, I just want to have some cool pics of him playing it). It's an easy camera to operate, just point and shoot. It must have some impressive image stabilization features because even handheld at maximum zoom, the pictures are clear. It weighs over a pound and its dimensions are aprox 4.5 x 3.5 x 4.5 inches. If you don't want use a bulky camera bag, I've found that it fits with some room to spare, in the "Zing 565-421 STB1 X-Large Stuff Pouch" which I purchased from this site.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Mega Zoom, but
Reviews.Author: cosmicgene
Reviews.Content: Best Point and Shoot with Mega Zoom.I owned Canon Rebel T1i DSLR, considered Panasonic DMC-FZ40, bought, used and returned Nikon P500 and Fuji Finepix S4000. So, I will give my take on Canon SX30IS from this perspective.I am updating it after using this for a recent trip and after taking couple of hundred photos and few dozen videos.I never wrote this long review. I want to help everyone who is contemplating between DSLR and point and shoot. Also, help decide between comparable and competing models: Fuji Finepix S4000, Panasonic DMC-FZ40, Nikon P500 and Canon SX30IS.DSLR (Canon T1i rebel)Positives: Excellent pictures, shortest shutter (non-existent) shutter lag, low light performance, burst speed that no point and shoot on earth will ever match. Only way to go for professional looking pictures that require greater detail.If you can pay up to $850, willing to carry a heavy camera bag with DSLR body, at least two lenses (one normal and one telephoto) and willing to spend time to change lens as the situation demands, go for the DSLR. Carrying a DSLR with 70-300mm zoom in your neck is no fun. It is more than two pounds handing down the neck. More number of times you change lens, more dust will accumulate on the mirror and sensor which may need professional cleaning at some point (every couple of years).I didn't want to carry a huge bag, do not want to change lens frequently, do not want to spend $600 and above for an all-in-one zoom lens alone(18-270 Tamron AF zoom goes for $479 with rebate). It costs close to $1000 for the type of DSLR I want with an all-in-one zoom that fits almost every 'picturable' situation and alleviates the need to change lens frequently and gives me respectable wide-angle and telephoto option. Hence, I returned T1i rebel to stick with a point and shoot.If you are a casual to semi-serious photographer who may want to share pictures, watch them on the monitor or TV, or print 10 x 14 size prints; then you don't notice much difference in image quality between T1i or Canon SX30IS (unless you take low-light, no flash pictures in less than ideal situation). If you want to capture low-light pictures all the time or high speed actions or spectacular shots for competitions, DSLR is the only way to go.Now, if you have decided that you don't want to go DSLR route, which PS (Point and shoot) is the next best.Why I didn't like these following cameras?Why not Fuji finepix S4000?Say, this is like a Kia Optima among the family sized sedans. OK quality and budget minded. 30X zoom but who cares if the lens quality and picture processing are mediocre.Horrendous movie capability. Totally unacceptable. Average picture quality. The camera looks and feels cheap. It is made in China and cannot come close to Japanese build cameras in terms of quality and durability. No offense to anyone, but in my opinion Japanese built cameras are the best. If you are on a budget, you can get this for $230 but you have to compromise on picture quality and live with the worst movie quality. If you want a quality camera, this not an option, despite its 30X zoom. Works on 4AA batteries, zoom is nice but noisy, picture quality is above average in good lighting conditions only.Why not Nikon P500?This is like a Toyota Camry limited edition. Not much different from DMC-FZ40, but way better than Fuji Finepix S4000.First of all, you don't get a battery charger. You have to charge it like a cell phone, directly hooking the charger to the camera. You can buy an after market battery and charger for extra money with arguable quality.Second, its auto focus is horrible. AF will try really hard to focus in low light conditions without much success and leading to blurred pictures. However, in outdoors, it can easily match Canon in overall picture quality. Its LCD is the best.Now, the third worst attribute. It cannot focus clearly while zoooming in a movie mode. While recording a movie, if you zoom, you will have blurred image until you stop zooming and allow the lens to refocus. If you plan to buy the camera for dual purpose (images vs. movies), this is not for you.Fourth and the most important is the image stabilization feature. Compared to Canon SX30IS, its image stabilization, at slightly higher zoom (15x and above) is pathetic. Its like comparing Kia with Lexus. Forget it. Canon is a hands down winner.If you can compromise on all these issues, you can buy this and save $20 over the Canon SX30IS.Features I liked that Canon SX30IS doesn't have: Sweep panorama. Camera records images while you sweep the camera and produces a panoramic picture. No software processing needed on a computer. Very convenient. In Canon SX30IS, you have to do this using 'stitch feature' and process it later with a software. For me, its not a deal breaker. It is also the lightest of these cameras, but Canon SX30IS isn't that heavy, just over a pound.Why not Canon SX30IS?I thought this is the answer for my search for the best point and shoot that can take very good quality pictures and videos with excellent zoom. But in the end, this is not the answer.This like a Toyota Camry, great overall sedan but not something that can knock you off with quality.Great zoom, nice pictures, ok movie quality. For some reason, the movies I shot tend to freeze and have no idea why. May be a bug in the camera software? Shutter lag is very high. Burst speed is very much non-existent. Painfully slow. Cannot capture fast moving actions in spur of the moment since camera take a while to respond, focus and capture the image.Pictures are soft and the color is way off. If I use vivid colors setting, reds are overblown and pictures are horrible. Overall, a decent camera but picture quality isn't razor sharp. Not what you expect from Canon. Indoor videos with decent light is grainy.If you don't have the memory card, can't capture even one image. On FZ40, you can capture upto 10 images of high resolution even if you happen to forget the memory card.Verdict: Not the best. Returned.My final choice:Panasonic DMC-FZ40.Say, this is like a Lexus among the family sedans. Good overall scores. Best camera for the buck.The zoom and autofocus of the camera are the best. Its zoom is the smoothest, fastest and quietest. You do not her any motor sound unless you are in a very quite room and listen very carefully. Outstanding.It can match or out perform Canon SX30IS in still picture quality (still testing). Only 24x zoom, but does the job in majority of situation. Power OIS is great. In fact, the pictures are much sharper and better color saturation over Canon or Nikon. FZ40 has excellent movie options that Canon SX30IS cannot match, especially indoors.Also, its shutter lag and burst options are excellent, better than Canon SX30IS.But, FZ40 is doesn't work well with after market spare battery and you must buy a Panasonic ($40 and above or 15% of the cost of the Camera) battery due to a security feature.  After market battery may work, but you don't have any information displayed (how much battery is left) etc. I have no problems shelling out extra bucks for a quality battery.I think this camera, with comparable or better picture quality and better movie quality than canon, is the my choice. Priced $120 below the Canon SX30IS, it is the best value for the money with outstanding quality. Moreover, its slightly smaller and lighter than Canon. I returned my SX30IS after the trip and bought this for $285.Finally, why I stuck with Panasonic FZ40 instead of T1i rebel?Its smaller, lesser weight and less than half the cost than DSLR with lens kit that can closely come to the range of 35X zoom that SX30IS offers.Positives: Great pictures for most users (up to 8 x 10 sheets with excellent detail), light weight compared to SX30IS, portability, amazing, quieter and faster zoom among the PS cameras (better zooming than Canon), the best HD movie quality for almost all practical purposes with continuous focus maintained during zooming, excellent low-light performance among any point and shoot once you know how to play with manual options and use a tripod, and best bang for the buck.Its shutter lag, start-up time, full-resolution burst speed (upto 2.5 shots/sec can be achieved without flash and high-speed SD card).FZ40 takes 52 mm lens. I had 58 mm lens kit, so I bought an adapter (52 to 58 mm step-up) to use.So, zoom is not everything and Panasonic FZ40 offers the best value for the money.

Reviews.Title: Quite Disappointed
Reviews.Author: AN
Reviews.Content: Sure, the product has an incredible zoom, but I feel like the image quality is much lower than I expected.  Not sure if I simply have too high of expectations, but the camera isn't meeting them.  I wanted crisp photos and this camera has not been able to produce them.

Reviews.Title: Happy Customer
Reviews.Author: snaphappy
Reviews.Content: I'm a long time user of Canon Cameras after my Rebel was destroyed by customs at the airport I decided to try the SX30IS so far I have been pleased with the pictures.  I have taken some crappy ones, but also some really good ones.  I really like theanti-shake feature after all when you get to be my age you need a little anti-shake.  Overall, I would recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Can you say AWESOME!!!
Reviews.Author: D. B. Pegalis "1/2 Mommy 1/2 Professional"

} } } Length:: 0:32 MinsOkay I have given up on the fact that even though I am crazy picture taken lady that no I will never completely figure out my 35mm, SLR camera and never have a black room (oh it pains me soooo to say). I got this one right before we went on our trip to germany for 3 weeks (got stranded by stupid hurricane). Anyway, I am going to post a video of a zoom of a castle in Heidelberg Germany. My husband who bought the SLR camera for I am guessing 600 bucks 4 years ago and ugh don't want to know how much he spent on lens, filters, bag etc...all of the extras. He would say...oh this is a good camera...mind you this was after he was much pissed off that I bought it. I thought "damn it I am the picture taker in the family and I am going to get something I can use!" I am very very very happy I did. My other camera is the 1st generation Panasonic DMC-TS1 Panasonic Lumix DMC-TS1 12MP Digital Camera with 4.6x Wide Angle MEGA Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 2.7 inch LCD (Orange) I have learned that when on vacation never leave with just one camera...always have one ready for backup and this is the best of the best.Keep in mind while I was holding the camera it wasn't on a tri-pod...just in my hands while 2 kids ran around and my husband was annoyed that I had stopped walking...;-)

Reviews.Title: Requires Extra Reading
Reviews.Author: Donald S Riding
Reviews.Content: After reading all of the reviews of this product in Amazon.com and some other websites, I purchased this camera in late June.  All of the reviewers except very few gave the camera a high rating, so I was disappointed that my first picture was of such low quality.  I read all of the reviews again, and discovered that three or four had written information that I had skipped because of all of the detail, but contained useful information.  You really cannot get good pictures in the auto mode.I have tried all of the other modes, read the manual carefully, and read other articles about f stops, aperture, and iso.  Now, I have experienced better quality pictures.  This camera requires more knowledge of photography than the regular point and shoot camera because you cannot get a quality picture using smart auto. However, the extra reading and practice has yielded some very good, high quality pictures. Canon SX30IS 14.1MP Digital Camera with 35x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 2.7 Inch Wide LCD

Reviews.Title: I LOVE this camera
Reviews.Author: Cathy H. Geraci "CathyG"
Reviews.Content: This camera is so intuitive you only need to read the manual to know a few of the buttons!  Macro shots of flowers, which I use frequently, gives true color and great shots!  I have not had the opportunity to try the 35x telephoto, but will be able to report after my trip back to South Africa this October.  My Canon I used last year also took great photos.  I don't expect this camera to be any different.Great camera for the money.  I would recommend it to anyone wanting a great all round camera.  I have not used the movie mode, so cannot comment on that either.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for amateurs!
Reviews.Author: kerrym
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera for people with amateur skills who want professional quality pictures.  I purchased this camera to take with me on a vacation to Bali and came back with terrific pictures and videos that everyone is complimenting.  I'm very happy with the purchase.The only thing I would change about the design is the view finder.  It can be a bit cumbersome for some shots as the screen opens up.  I would prefer it to be embedded in the camera.  That said, the swivel function is good and helps you position the camera to get the best shot.

Reviews.Title: Not as Good as the SX20 Which Was Only Martginally Better than the SX10
Reviews.Author: Ethan A. Winning "ewin64"
Reviews.Content: This review could be summed up as follows: Take a really good lens with IS, a comfortable, light-weight body, and screw it up by overloading its processor with unnecessary capabilities.I bought and returned the SX30 after two weeks and, because I had some trepidation about a return, I bought locally rather than through Amazon which is my favorite "retailer." When I saw that Canon had brought out a 30x IS digital zoom, and 60% of my photos are of birds, I was bummed that I had just gotten the SX20IS. If you know waterfowl at all, you know they tend to sit in the middle of a pond. They do not come 20 feet from you and pose. In 2010, I has seven of my photos published in birding magazines (and eight of muskrats, spiders and dragonflies in nature mags). You can see these photos on my web site which, because Amazon has to be careful, can only be described as my first and last name.com.Why the preface? It's necessary, that's why. Too many people do not realize that the more bells and whistles Canon (and the rest) put on a camera diminishes the capability of the chip to handle the bells or the whistles or both.The SX10 and the SX20 had one problem which was bad enough, and just got worse with the SX30: low light photos are terrible or terribly hard. I'm not speaking of taking pictures of a birthday party when at least you might have light from the conflagration of Aunt Marta's 91 candles lighting up the room. I'm talking about an overcast day, even a day when it's bright, but no sunlight. The kind of day when a 35mm camera could compensate and using film with an ASA of 400 didn't create so much noise that you tossed the photo.With the Canons, a subject at 50 feet under the canopy of a tree is darn near impossible. And don't use the flash because with animals' retinas reflect white or grey which cannot be corrected with red-eye correction. And with raptors, don't even think of PhotoShop to get rid of grey eye.If that was all, I would have kept the camera for sunny day shooting. But no, there are other negatives as well. A preface to this list is that I REALLY WANTED this to work. Who wouldn't? The equivalent of over 700mm telephoto in a 20 ounce camera would bet the dream of any nature photographer.Pros: It does take decent - not fantastic - photos at full zoom under the right conditions.Canon brought back the tether for the lens cap. Whoopee! Took 'em long enough and makes you wonder if they read comments from end-users.Cons: Low-light photography is difficult if not impossible, and I use everything from A, V, and M to Program and Auto and all those special circumstance lighting (e.g., night or fireworks) to no avail.Canon went to a proprietary battery instead of my AA rechargeable batteries which I have been using on the SX10 and 20 as well as every other gadget in my arsenal. (The Eneloops will last long enough for about 700 photos taken at full resolution including some flash shots.) I carry a set of those batteries in the car, and a set in my pocket when I remember. They hold their charge for well over a year, but that's another review.The difference between 24mm and 28mm wide-angle doesn't make much of a difference to me even when taking shots of Yosemite Valley. There comes a point when reality is compromised. I know full well when, at one time 20 years ago, I became enamored with my Olympus Zuiko fish eye lens and for about a year, the whole world was presented as a small-mouth bass would see it.This camera is slooooooow. Even on a good day, i.e., sunny, you can't snap off 3-5 shots in less than 8-10 seconds. Reset is also slow, and I suggest you turn off the LCD and use viewfinder only.The difference between 12.1 and 14 MP is negligible. First of all, by pushing the SX30 to 14.1 MP, the software and CMOS has to struggle to do everything that is asked of it. I want to make a point that I do not use PhotoShop: what I see is most often what I get with one exception. I am not opposed to cropping. I can take a photo with the SX20 and crop it and get a better photo than the SX30. If I were to put up some of my dragonfly and damselfly photos, anyone who has used these two (or three) cameras would know that the sharper images can from the SX20. They would have more difficulty in determining those taken with the SX10 and SX20.The macro is neither better now worse than the SX20. Oddly, my wife's teeny Canon SD1100IS 8MP takes better macros and super-macros than either of these. The best part of the S3, S5, SX10, SX20, and SX30 is the articulated LCD and the only time I use it is for macros or when I have to aim over a fence.While I should be thrilled that my SX20 is good for a few more years (or months), I'm terribly disappointed, in part because I want to stick to a "point-and-shoot" (a misnomer for anything this sophisticated). I do not want to fall into the trap of a DSLR with a body and 4 lenses and 35 pounds of stuff to carry with me. Besides, I've already made my reputation as "The Point-and-shoot Nature Photographer." I like having the skill set to use these Canons, but I do wish that Canon didn't feel it necessary to sell me something like the SX30 just because six months has gone by and the LAW is that they have to come up with something new every 6 months.Last word: Note that the description of the camera and the shots taken by the camera were all taken in bright light. When the SX40 comes out - unless this is Canon's way of forcing everyone into a DSLR - I'll try it if they show a photo of a bird in a tree, Aunt Marta's 92 birthday indoors, and an indoor graduation ceremony from 100 feet away. Oh, and then, I want a macro of a jumping spider showing all 8 eyes tack sharp.

Reviews.Title: Just too good for the price.. (I bought it when it was $369)
Reviews.Author: Padmanabhan
Reviews.Content: What else do u need? 35x Optical Zoom with full manual controls, Aperture Priority and Shutter priority and what not... This camera can perform even better than many of the known DSLRs if a person knows proper photography... A really good investment...The VDO capabilities might not be that good... but the rest of the features and quality super-cedes that... A must buy for people looking to shoot professional photographs without investing in an SLR..

Reviews.Title: Great Camera For Wildlife
Reviews.Author: LeeG
Reviews.Content: As an amateur+ photographer having done so and owned many cameras through the years, this camera answers most of my many wants.I was pleasantly surprised at the ease of use. most of those complaining about it probably haven't gone through the effort of reading the manual, which is very thorough. A printed version with the camera would have been nice. The 35X zoom is a "WOW ITEM", for someone like me that spends loads of time in wildlife refuges. Still using a EOS 20D, but taking the big lenses along became more of a problem in the field. This camera solves most of that problem, being light in weight, easily used on a mono-pod, and having a great stabilization. I can easily recommend this camera to those interested in wildlife, birds, etc., as a second camera for those special times when the more professional SLR's become unwieldy. Since my purchase, I've taken aver a thousand pics, and probably less than 5% weren't as expected, probably due to haste, wrong settings or errors on my part. All in all, a very good camera at a good cost. No complaints so far.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: David Ryan
Reviews.Content: I had purchased a Koday which claimed 26X and had returned it. The pictures were not as good as with the Canon SX10is I have been using. Purchasing the SX30is was a leap of faith as I really didn't believe the claims that I had read. But it was well worth the investment. It is faster when using the flash and I can take photos of distant objects or scenery that was impossible before. Also you can purchase extra batteries at a more than reasonable price. I strongly recommend this camera for anyone.

Reviews.Title: CANON POWERSHOT SX30
Reviews.Author: killahca$h
Reviews.Content: This camera is simply stunning, the zoom is awesome for a portable camera. Takes amazing pics and video. I read all the reviews and did all my research before throwin down $400. I am a hugh Canon fan, have the Canon EOS 50D and the Canon T2i and I am very happy with the support of Canon products.The camera is a little bigger than I thought it would be but its not a big deal really considering the zoom and the swivel lcd screen. The camera would be great for sporting events and concerts and outdoor use.Would recommend getting a filter and hood for the camera.This camera is a great excellent replacement or alternative to a digital slr camera.

Reviews.Title: I cannot understand the Reviewers that rate this Camera 1 Star
Reviews.Author: Pushpakant N. Kulkarni "PKulkarni"
Reviews.Content: Today's Camera's are very sophisticated and unless you are a Camera buff with great inclination for Photography, you are not going to be good at using these cameras.  Stick to the point and shoot cameras.  Sit down and take some time to read the manual and play with all the buttons to understand what each button does.  Understand the features of the camera. I have learnt over time that if you are going to use a large zoom factor, everything is magnified.  Even a small movement is amplified 35 times.  So use a TRIPOD to take those far away pictures.  This is a NO-BRAINIER. the F numbers or the F-Stops as they were referred to in the old days, are aperture sizes.  The smaller the number the larger the opening and larger the F-stop smaller the aperture opening.  Smaller aperture openings tent to give sharper images across the entire photo shot. The older film cameras had a button to check the depth of field at various aperture openings.  That gave you an idea what is in focus and what is not at that F#.Do not knock the camera just because you do not understand the intricasies of the camera or the technology.  I know that the camera manufacturers offer features that are not always equal to or the same as the other manufacturers.  You need to do your due deligence to determine what camera will give you the biggest bang for your buck.It is amazing that there are quite a few folks that give a great review while a handful give the camera a bad review.  This is ridiculous and impossible.  The camera cannot be excellent on one hand and terrible on the other hand......

Reviews.Title: The SX30 IS
Reviews.Author: Philip Sydell "The Artist"
Reviews.Content: The camera has a great deal to offer.  The zoom lens does a wonderful job in its optical mode and the fact that there is a viewfinder in addition to a viewing screen is a big plus.  It make it easier to take pictures hand held.  The ability to rotate and reposition the viewing screen is a great improvement over many cameras on the market today.  It allows you to shoot over the heads of people or holding the camera at waste level. It is a wonderful attribute.ConsThe pictures have one fault that I can see and that is a blue line around many of the edges that you have to filter out.The camera cannot take Raw ImagesThere is no custom setting for white balanceThe buttons on the right side of the camera for unzooming, previewing the pictures that you have taken and setting the exposure for over or underexposing your shots are right under your hand when you are holding the camera.  It is difficult not to hit one or more of these buttons when you are shooting, thus spoiling your shot.Generally speaking, the camera is a fine piece of equipment and quite versatile.  For it's price and weight it is a wonderful instument to take pictures when you don't feel like carrying a SLR and a lot of lenses.  This lens goes from wide angle to 35x optical zoom and that is something.I do suggest that you buy a monopod to go with the camera since there are limits to image stabilization, especially in low light when you choose not to use a flash or prefer not to.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for everyday shooting...SOCCER MOM'S BUY!
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: I was very impressed with this camera and would recommend it for any family photo takers out there or just anyone wanting a step up from the cheapest/simplest point and shoot cameras.Pros:-Awesome zoom! Unheard of for other point and shoots, and would be very expensive lens for any other DSLR-Great auto settings for those who like it simple, and great manual settings for people looking to experiment-Great built in flash-Flip out LCD is very handy-Very small form factor for what it offers, looking at it you would have no idea it zooms so far-Feels and looks a lot more professionalCon:-limited features due to it not being a full scale DSLR-zoom a little annoyingly loudOverall-Not a true DSLR, but it does what it is meant for very well(which is offer more features, a huge zoom, and image stabilization) and I would highly recommend it to anyone wanting just a step up from a cheap point and shot without the complexity and cost of a Canon Rebel/other DSLRIf this isn't good enough the next step camera would be the(in order of cost) Canon Rebel XSi, Rebel T1i, Rebel T2i, D60.I have the T2i and love it (the Rebel XSi didn't look too appealing to me), very good camera for size and cost. I would say this is the next good step past the SX30. Or the T1i which is VERY similar. Look closely at the details of the T1, T2, and T3 before choosing.I also have the D60. This is the next step past the T2i. It is a little bigger, heavier, and feels more rugged than the T2i but very similar is most respects.
