The T3i is almost identical in features to the D60, but at that point I would go for the D60.

Reviews.Title: Got what I expected.
Reviews.Author: Jim
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera after having read dozens of reviews and watching several review videos.  Many of them speak about the low-light picture quality being a little worse (when compared to other similar cameras).  I think the low-light picture issue is a slight problem.  If that's your primary need, then I would avoid this camera.  I wish I could have given 4 and half stars instead of 5 for that reason.However, it has been the only problem I've found since getting the camera and running a few dozen test pictures and video over the last two weeks.  But, when compared to my previous camera, the low-light picture quality is much better (7 megapixel Kodak).  One area that is absolutely wonderful is the video quality.  This camera is now my perferred method of taking video.  (I was using a Mini DV camera before.)Of course, if you're reading this review, it's because the 35X zoom caught your attention.  Yes, it's everything you expect.  Probably the most important feature with the zoom is the button that pulls the picture back so you can find your subject again...and then it goes back to the original telephoto setting once you release the button.  It does this quickly and is a great help when zoomed in very tightly.The menu system is a little confusing at times.  But I've already mastered the items I use the most.  Recently, I was using this camera on the ski slopes and found that the zoom and the "snow" setting worked very well.  Also, I could get the camera out of the case, turned on, and taking pictures in just seconds.  Several of my videos required zooming in on a subject that was more than 100 yards away.  The image stabilization worked well during these shots.If you're looking for a general all around "mega zoom" camera, then this should be one of the finalist in your search.

Reviews.Title: What is WRONG with the picture quality?
Reviews.Author: C. Butler
Reviews.Content: This is my first Canon, which I bought after using different Kodaks for eight years. Being a newspaper reporter, I have training as a photographer, and I have even won two photography awards for my work in newspapers (even though I am primarily a writer), so I'm hardly a novice when it comes to cameras. I take about 2,000 pictures per year that I add to my personal collection.I decided it was time for me to evolve beyond Kodak and onto some of the better, more expensive brands (the sales reps strongly referred me to get either Canon or Nikon, which are supposedly the two best brands). My Kodak had 8 MP and 12X zoom capacity. I've missed out on some great shots because 12X zoom capacity simply wasn't enough. I was attracted to this Canon camera specifically because of the 35X zoom capacity. I never once questioned what the quality of the photos would be, given Canon's reputation, and give the fact that this camera has more megapixels.I saved up enough money for this camera and bought it just in time for the holidays......UNFORTUNATELY, the pictures I took with this camera are no better quality-wise than the pictures I've taken with my iPhone (which might have all of 4 MP). I seriously regret selling my Kodak (which produced rich, VIBRANT photos) in favor of this Canon. I am honestly befuddled at how a $400 camera could end up producing photos that are inferior in quality to my $200 Kodak (and this is even AFTER I used my computer to enhance the photos).I think I'm going to have to sell this camera in favor of something better, because these low-quality photos are simply unacceptable (and yes, I DID READ THE OWNER'S MANUAL, especially the part about pressing the shutter button halfway at first).FOLLOW UP (12-26-10): I have been reading the 196 page instruction manual (which is only available by uploading a CD into your computer. The paper version that comes in the box is extremely short and NOT nearly as detail-oriented, which was another mistake on Canon's part).I see I have a long way to go toward learning how to work this thing. I have noticed that if I keep the camera on Portrait mode AND standard single shot mode at the same time then I will produce the same high quality images I got out of my old Kodak. Unfortunately, so far, the images in every other setting are still grainy. I will update as warranted (any advice is most appreciated).FOLLOW UP (12-27-10): I am learning more about this model (see the responses to this review) and suggest that anyone having problems spend the proper amount of time familiarizing themselves with the 200-page instruction manual (as opposed to the 30 page one). This is a very complex camera, but one I believe will take quality pictures if the owner is willing to evolve beyond what is simple (that's why I bought this camera in the first place) and have a better grasp of the mechanics of photography. Lowering the ISO to 80 or 100, for instance, will make for a sharper image.

Reviews.Title: What I have Been Waiting For!
Reviews.Author: J. Dyess "greenrug"
Reviews.Content: Just love this Canon sx30 for enabling me to get close to the bird and animal life that I live around. I finally discovered the fishing habits of the kingfisher. That some wild ducks eat fish. That dew drops on flowers shine in the mornings sunrise.AND, the concerns about picture quality seem to be refuted by the online photo postings as they  are breathtaking. Love the lithium battery rather than constantly feeding it store bought batteries as I did with my sx10is. Bravo Canon. I couldn't be more pleased.

Reviews.Title: SX30 IS Works well
Reviews.Author: Gary K
Reviews.Content: I brought this camera refurbished by Canon. It works well. I bought it for the 35X optical and 14.1 megapixels so that I can take close photos of birds and animals in my yard. In addition, I wanted to make enlargements as well. So far photos look good. I have had other Canon cameras and with little help I can take good photos. However, this time I need to read the manual more it has lots of extras to take advantage of.

Reviews.Title: A Work Horse
Reviews.Author: J. Esteban
Reviews.Content: I have one these hanging on a peg board right by my doorway.  It has an extra long 3/4 inch nylon strap with a small accessory bag containing lens cleaners, a plastic bag and an extra SDHC 32G memory card.  I always add one of the OptechUSA neoprene bags and the whole systems hangs there begging for me to take it with me where ever I go. The camera is so light that I found it's a waste of time and energy to carry the monopod around any more.  I just put the thing in the palm of my hand and I can hold it there for an hour easily. I love taking HD video with this baby.  The controls on these camera's have been basically the same for the last five years.  The video is great and the audio performance is magnificent. With a 32G SDHC I think I get about 7.5 minutes per Gig so I have about 4 hours of video if my batteries last that long.  It does have and adapter for an external flash that I never use but whose to say what will happen tomorrow.  The flash is pretty strong and I use it often.  The video performance is incredible. It has a little control for adjusting the brightness of the video while it's running and I have found that to be extremely useful in low light conditions.  I often take video in doors during church and you can get pretty reasonable images off of the video at 150 to 300 dpi.  The cool thing about shooting the video is that you don't have to keep the camera still all of the time and when you review the video your getting 30 frames per second so your almost always going have some images that are worth keeping if your relatively careful and steady with the camera.  I purchased an extra charger and battery and I always grab a new battery on my way out.  I've shot up to 12 Gigs of video with one battery. The battery and memory are in the same compartment which is a slight nuisance since you will have to remove any quick disconnect adapters in order to open the compartment.  The good news is that 32G cards are readily available and the batteries last a long time so you never really have to get into that compartment very often in normal use.  The zoom lens is quiet and smooth.  It's not completely linear but it is repeatable and easy to get use to. My only real gripe is that it's not easy to use manual focus.  If you want to focus on an animal that's behind some brush the only sensible thing to do is to focus on something else about that distance away and hold the button in it's first position and move the camera over to take the picture. Having said that I've had one of these since the days of the S2IS and as long as they keep improving them and selling them for about $300 to $400 I'll probably keep buying them.

Reviews.Title: Good and Bad
Reviews.Author: lwp99
Reviews.Content: I have several other Canon products, including the "heavy" lenses for my digital DSLR's - I like Canon cameras. I bought the SX30 IS for traveling when I didn't want to carry all the weight. I was pleasantly surprised by the clarity with the telephoto zoomed all the way out - made the purchase seem like a good buy. However, the pictures taken with the flash are poor. The subject is identifiable, but there is no crispness - and lots of speckles. I use my other camera when quality pictures with flash are important. Admittedly, the lense/body combination is much more expensive, but for special occasions such as pictures of children and grandchildren, the quality is significantly better. I'd bought the SX30 IS hoping to find a good "all around" camera. Unfortunately, the poor quality pictures with flash make this a difficult product to recommend without the qualifications.

Reviews.Title: Bought it as a gift--Husband loved it!
Reviews.Author: Bonnie D. "bondem777"
Reviews.Content: This is an extremely high quality camera for the price.  I'm no techiie, just a wife who bought a gift, but my husband loves it and he's taking the most amazing pictures.  He posted this absolutely beautiful picture of a mountain view that looked like it came out of a magazine.  Then I realized it was the view from my back yard!  Can't rave enough about this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Martha G. Howell
Reviews.Content: My son heard me say that I was looking for an economically priced zoom camera that I could use for birding & wildlife photography.  He found this one on Amazon & with his knowledge of cameras, highly recommended it.  So far I am really pleased with it's performance & am eager to visit Pea Island WR in the Outer Banks of NC to get some good shots of waterfowl.  I am extremely pleased with my purchase.

Reviews.Title: Too good to be true
Reviews.Author: happyband
Reviews.Content: The feature set is terrific. Having the 840mm available is very useful and I find myself just leaving it fully extended and looking for subjects to shoot from 10 feet to a mile away....However, there must be plenty of light in order to enable a shutter speed of at least 1/250. Faster is even better.Low light focus is slow and inaccurate. My Panasonics and other Canons do a better job more consistently. Image sharpness is not as high as my other cameras and I have to work harder in Photoshop to get an equally sharp photo but it never really gets to a high enough level of sharpness. On balance, I will use the sx30 when I need the extreme zoom and will use my Canon G12 for everything else. The G12 does produce really sharp and detailed pictures.720 movies are terrific. This is a feature I didn't need but am using a lot anyway. It is a little hard to hold the camera out from my head for long shots but the eyelevel finder, which image is very small, works ok for video even though it is pretty crude in sharpness to look at. Having autofocus and zoom for video in a still camera is awesome and appreciated. There is an intermittent vignetting in the lower right corner during video of a moving things like horses and cars. It might be the Image Stabilization trying to keep up with the movement during video shooting. It's not crucial but should not be there at this stage of technology. I would like an easier way to adjust the shutter speed and aperture manually. You have to switch back and forth now and do not have both displays open at once. However, there is a lot good value there for $400 and we will use this camera on photo safari this summer.

Reviews.Title: I love the Canon SX30IS!
Reviews.Author: Erinjoy510
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!  It is so easy to use and I am just getting into photography so it is perfect.  There aren't too many features or difficult screens to navigate.  The only issue I had was figuring out how to get the Flash hot shoe off.  With an easy online video from YouTube though I found it!  Recommended by avid Canon users!

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera!
Reviews.Author: Jessica Mikel Williams
Reviews.Content: I love, love, love this camera!  It is by far the best camera I have ever owned.  It is so easy to use, and takes awesome pictures!  The pictures are so clear and they look like a professional took them instead of an amateur like me!

Reviews.Title: Amazing zoom!
Reviews.Author: soccer dad
Reviews.Content: I have had this camea for a few weeks, and am still learning about the many functions.  Camera was purchased because of the zoom, and it certainly delivers!  I'd planned to include pictures taken with no zoom (looking at bookcase across the room- 20+ feet away), max optical zoom (can see several books clearly), and max digital zoom (6 letters from title on spine of 1 book- I did use tripod on last shot).  Unfortunately I'm not seeing how to add photo's to the review.  Truly amazing zoom, and I can e-mail them if your interested.In addition to zoom, I wanted quick start up, good photo quality, and good burst capability for capturing the perfect shot at daughter's soccer games.  Camera delivers on all but the burst.  I am going to play with taking video and printing a still from that.  You can snap a photo while taking video, but may not get just the right instant.I consider myself a novice user, and even though this camera doesn't do everything I wanted automatically, right out of the box, I think it's a great camera and a great deal.  I have had difficulty taking night photos when I don't want a bright flash (like Christmas lights on our house), but I expect that the camera is probably capable of much more, and I just need to catch up to it.

Reviews.Title: Overall, this camera is OK, not great.
Reviews.Author: Ethan Turner
Reviews.Content: This camera is capable of capturing high-quality photos, but only when you have good light, a subject which fills most of the frame, and you set the ISO to to 80 or 100 (as is normally done in good light).  I've had mine over 1 year and used it for several purposes, including family vacation photos and also for documentation purposes at work.  It's held together just fine.  Because it's your typical slow, clunky, point-and-shoot, I don't use it for sports or action photos at all.  For those things, I use a DSLR.  In most photos from this camera, I notice both graininess and softness when viewed at full size.  The zoom 35x is a good feature to have, but it don't count on having quality images when you max out the zoom.  If you want high quality shots from this camera, you should use it a close range and in good light.Besides not needing to change lenses, the only advantage I can see for this camera vs. a DSLR is the fact that it does shoot fairly good video.  However, it's not ergonomically good to hold it and shoot video for a long perid of time.  You'll get tired and you might even drop it.  But, if you have the need for occasional, short video clips, it's great.Also, it's worth noting that the price has actually risen on this camera since I purchased it.  When I bought it last year, it was $400 plus shipping.  At the time of this review, it's gone up to $450.  Given my experience with it this camera, one of it's predecessors, and several DSLR's, I would not pay $450 for it.  Knowing what I know now, I'd give no more than $350 for this camera.

Reviews.Title: Very nice, indeed!
Reviews.Author: Z_Cowboy
Reviews.Content: This camera was purchased to replace my old Nikon N6006 35mm SLR. I wasn't sure if I wanted to dabble into high end digital SLR's since I have less and less time for hobby photography and this little gem simplifies all the casual capture of memorable moments! The picture quality is mostly exceptional; the few goofs are usually user mistakes in settings and excessive unsteadiness. With the addition of 8 gig memory cards and an extra battery, you can skip all the bulky extras the 35mm camera dictated. A whole weeks' vacation can be captured by simply carrying a fanny pack! Video quality is also exceptional; with great motion stability and smooth, gradual zoom. While on the subject of zooming, the wide range of coverage is fantastic! Until I am ready to dive back into high end photography as a hobby again, this camera is a marvelous everyday camera!

Reviews.Title: Must buy!!!
Reviews.Author: K. Shattles "Avid reader, TX"
Reviews.Content: I have only had it a couple of weeks but I am very impressed with the features of this camera.  Not only is it Canon quality but the zoom capability alone is worth the price!  Then you get the Special Scene modes which includes a fish eye effect, the ability to choose one focus color and have the rest of the scene in black and white.  I love these two features and plan to experiment with many photos.The camera is bigger than I like for my point and shoots, but I had to have this camera!!  I know two other people who received it as gifts a month before my purchase and they were also very happy with this camera!

Reviews.Title: First (of many) Digital Cameras that I didn't like
Reviews.Author: Bob
Reviews.Content: I purchased my Canon Powershot SX30IS to replace my Canon Powershot S3, which had unexpectedly stopped working. For a bit of background, most of my photo shooting is done while hiking and Geocaching. I take a LOT of shots, animals, insects, plants, dew drops, whatever caches my eye at the time. I really like getting in close, especially with insects and plants. Further, most of the time I'm taking "snapshots". Photos where I don't have much time to set-up, take readings, steady the camera, etc. I'm talking about a grasshopper that happens to land within a foot of me or a fellow hiker doing something photo worthy at the spur of the moment.I've had the camera for some months now and have formed some opinions. On the good side the 35X optical zoom is great. I was able to get a fantastic, tight framed close up of a Red Tailed Hawk sitting on a fence post, seemingly glaring back at me. Because of the type of shots I often take, the tiltable/adjustable LCD screen is one of the most useful functions on the camera (I'd have a hard time going without one). My videos always come out just fine, though I don't often use that capability. Being able to zoom in and out without pausing the video is a nice bonus.Now, the not so good, regrettably, there is more I dislike about the camera than I like. The unit replaced my old S3, which was rather bulky, but I was still able to carry it on my hikes in a pouch on my belt. Not so with the SX30IS. This sucker is big and bulky. The only practical way to carry it is either in my backpack, which makes it inaccessible for snapshots, or as I usually carry it, on a neck strap, where it's always in danger of being snagged or bumped on something hard, not to mention... it's a pain in the neck, literally.There are two buttons, that after many hundreds of shots, I still accidently, on a very regular basis, activate. The first is the "menu" button, which by the way the camera fits in my hands, my palm hits this button simply by virtue of holding the camera. The other, is the "zoom framing assist" button. This button, in concept is really an innovative idea. When zooming on a distant subject, it can be very hard to locate your target, the zoom assist, when pressed, zooms out, and once you find your subject you release the button and it goes right back to the zoomed in level originally chosen. The problem, it's made too convenient, right on the very edge where your thumb naturally grasps the camera. Activating either of these functions when not intended  is very distracting and cause for missing desired shots.The previously mentioned dislikes are minor compared to my main complaints. As already mentioned, I take mostly snapshots, and need the camera to focus and adjust the exposure quickly and accurately. This is where the camera really falls down on the job. Using the "Smart" AUTO function the majority of my shots are both out-of-focus and poorly exposed. I'm not talking sometimes, or half the time, I'm talking MOST OF THE TIME. I guess the more accurate "Dumb AUTO" would not have been a good selling point. After much experimenting, now my default setting is "P" (programmed AE), which usually (not nearly "always") gives me well focused shots, but, in anything other than bright full sunlight, usually gives me poorly exposed shots, with extreme pixelation.More on exposures, it is not rare at all to need/desire fill flash, but, alas, to do so with this camera requires a complex, time consuming, set of steps and often the auto-exposure results are still unacceptable.The macro close-up function also provides very inconsistent/poor results. I've had excellent results with previous cameras, getting hand-held shots of, for example, a honey bee gathering pollen at the end of a wispy flower stem, while simply holding lens very near the insect but not taking the time to use the view finder (or LCD). Not with this camera. You would consider yourself lucky if you get 1 out of 5 shots to come out as usable... and that's taking the time to use the LCD.My decision to purchase this camera was based on my general satisfaction with my previous camera, a Canon Powershot S3, which had its weak points, but was overall a good camera that took a beating on the trails and gave me some great photographs with a minimum of effort. Then there were the "professionally written" reviews, which mostly highly praised this camera. What little negatives I found had always been followed with a counter offsetting positive point guiding me away from potential problems. I researched this purchase much more than previous digital cameras and it turned out to be my worst.I'm no "photographer", I'm a hobbyist that has expectations built up from years of "playing" with cameras and having what I believe to be reasonable expectations for a point and shoot camera.  As an unequal comparison, but providing me with some minimum standards, I have a very old Sony DSC-W5 that I use as a back-up camera, it is a rare event that I get a poorly exposed shot and out-of-focus shots are as rare as a 5 megapixal camera. It only requires a single button press to force the flash for fill. Alas, after years of use, at some point this camera has picked up some lens aberrations on the edges and can't be trusted to fill my needs.The Canon Powershot SX30IS camera has not nearly lived up to expectations and I would not recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Great Superzoom!
Reviews.Author: Chris
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera from Amazon for Christmas as a replacement for my 3mp Fuji S5000.  The 35x zoom is what ultimately sold me.  As I learn to use the light my pictures are getting much better.  I am constantly amazed at some of the picture I am getting with handheld 35x zoom.  I posted some pics from an icestorm we recently had and a bluebird with differnt crop sizes so you can seed the detail captured at 35x.  I find pictures come out much bette in P mode with the setting at 80iso on sunny days.  I am very much an amateur and never bothered to learn the advanced settings on my Fuji since the auto mode was excellent.  The auto mode on the sx30 isn't as good so I am forced to learn more about the advanced settings.  I wish there were more settings for file size.  It goes from 14mp to 7mp then 2mp and .3mp.  The continuous shooting is also very slow.  I turned off the preview and the lag time between pics is a little faster, but still slow.  A rubberized exterior would have been nice too.  All in all I love this camera and go out almost daily to look for bluebirds.  I have gotten some amazing shots and am glad I purchased it.

Reviews.Title: A decent super-zoon
Reviews.Author: S. Vogt
Reviews.Content: I've seen a lot of comments on this camera about this image quality is poor. I guess if you're a "pixel peeper" then maybe you might have issues with this camera. I am very picky and notice details in pictures and I can say that I don't see a degredation in photo quality between this and the SX10 IS (which I previously owned).I think folks also get the impression that it's akin to a DSLR when it most certainly is not. I fault Canon partially for marketing it as such.The camera is not small but I think it's of a size where it makes it comfortable to grip and easy to use. Although the camera does seem a little smaller than the SX10 and SX20. The camera has lots of features and offers a full manual set of shooting features which are very easy to manipulate if you're into manual shooting. I like the Electronic Viewfiner... comes in very handy in bright, sunny conditions when the LCD is not easily visible. The LCD swings out and swivels. Unfortunatley it's somewhat low resolution. I find the overall layout of the camera very easy to use and navigate through - it's pretty similar to most of the other Canon point and shoots. It also has a hot shoe for adding things like an external flash. Unfortunatley it does not support RAW photos like the Panasonic does.The photo quality is very good - on par with other high-end point and shoots. Good color saturation and decent sharpness. Although, again, you would not confuse it for a DSLR. The 35x zoom works well, although, as with other aspects of the cameras performance, operates at a rather leisurely pace. This camera is not reccomended for action shots - in the Superzoom category - the Panasonic Lumix FZ100 is a better choice if you want fast performance.I reccomend this camera for folks who want a little more than your average point and shoot and also it's a decent choice for newbie photography hobbyists. It packs a lot of features and has fairly respectable photo quality. But again, it's not for action shots and it's also not pocketable.

Reviews.Title: Best P&S; I had
Reviews.Author: A. Gift For You "SK"
Reviews.Content: In my search for a decent zoom P&S;, I have tried couple cameras (for around a month each) including the Nikon P100 and of course the Canon SX30 IS. I have to say, the Canon beat the others in many aspects. Although the sensor is small given the 14MP cramped to it, the images are very pleasing. For example, the noise level is way less than the P100 (which has a CMOS sensor).  Also, you can reduce ISO up to 80 in good light conditions, which greatly reduces the noise.  The zoom is so powerful and the stabilizer works like a charm.  The flip LCD also comes in handy in different situations where the VF or a fixed LCD is not enough. You can maneuver the LCD the way you like. What made this one pops in respect to the other zoom P&S; is the flexibility. Once you improve your photo skills you will want to explore new things.  It has hot shoe for external flash, which would be a necessity for portrait, indoor or nice micro shots.  Using a lens adapter, you can use filters (both screw in or slide (Cokin, for example) which facilitates having great landscape pictures.  It has s lot more features and cool things, but no time to mention them here. Although it does not shoot in RAW, has a remote shutter, or has long lapse shooting...etc, many of these features (and more) can be unlocked and become feasible using CHDK (if necessary and when ready for this camera). (I wont say what CHDK is, you can google it yourself...).Now, the draw back: the only two things that I miss in this camera compared to others i tried are1- fps (frames per second), which is low in this one compared to others like P100 that use CMOS. P100 was able to shoot 40fps in burst more which was neat!!! Also, due to the fast rate, the P100 had a slow motion video capabilities.2- The build. P100 was metallic (maybe aluminum), which made it look like sturdy and able to take couple accidental bumps now and then. This one is made of plastic. So far it is good (not cheap one), but not sure what will happen in the future! I will definitely buy an extended warranty with accidental coverage for it.

Reviews.Title: daylebread
Reviews.Author: daylebread
Reviews.Content: Bought the sx30IS to replace my other powershot.  Bought this model because of the zoom.  This camera is awesome.  The 35x zoom is amazing.  It is very easy to use.  There is no blur from shaking.  I use a 8gig class 6 micro sdhc card which works great in the camera.  It is worth the 5 stars!

Reviews.Title: Somewhat Short Sweet and Simple
Reviews.Author: S. Bronsak
Reviews.Content: All my cameras have been Canon to include the SX10, which I love.  This new SX30 is:slow in operation,not smooth operating (jerky and noisy lens),there's very little difference in zoom from the SX10 (I expected a noticeable difference probably setting myself up for this disappointment),and the new style is uncomfortable to my hand compared to the earlier version because it has a smaller grip area.Didn't care for the change from using regular batteries to now using a rechargeable battery pack.I think Canon took a big step back in this new model!The purchase went back to the store within the first 24 hours.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera!
Reviews.Author: Alex
Reviews.Content: The camera is excellent and has a large number of resources to take good pictures. But we strongly recommend reading the manual, because even in AUTO mode, the photographer must press the shutter button halfway to focus, and then tightening them to shoot (even in automatic modes, the user must have a minimum of knowledge of the camera).I think that many complain about the image quality by not knowing how to use the various features of the camera (not knowing how to use the automatic features and the various resource manuals) or wait for the quality of a DSLR.If all machine resources are used, the photographer can get close to this quality of DSLR, but SX30IS is not a DSLR! See the pictures I posted in the gallery that show the strength and quality of the maximum zoom (840 mm - 35X) and image stabilizer. All photos taken by hand, without tripod!Pros:- The 35X zoom is really impressive and the image stabilization is spectacular. In the requirement zoom and image stabilization, there are no competitors that come near the SX30IS. You can get excellent pictures by hand using the 35X zoom. But in low light conditions the user must know how to use the resources and / or tripod to get sharp photos. (When using a tripod, the image stabilization must be switched off)- The menu is easy to use and intuitive. The LCD Flip-out screen is the best among the competitors, being very clear.- There are several features to take great photos. I'm still reading the manual and I can not use all resources, but the pictures and movies are improving as I know the camera better.- The movies are good qualityCons:- The greatest shortcoming of the camera is to have low FPS, because the camera does not take many pictures per second. In this variable the superzoom competitors are way better.- Do not shoot in full HD, though HD movies are already very good. It could have 3-inch screen instead of 2.7.- No High-speed frame rate (slow motion) in the movies. This feature is present in the competitors. But you can see the movies in slow motion in the camera (not the same thing already burn in slow motion).Thus, I considered this an excellent camera, especially because I'm still learning to use the various features, and photos are improving. I bought a tripod, a Canon 270EX flash, Canon filter adapter and Tiffen filter polarizer, which are greatly improving my photos.I'm still waiting for my Canon 270EX flash, which I believe will greatly improve my indoor photos, completion, macro and portraits (bounce flash)The tripod has greatly improved the pictures in low light.And now that I'm using Canon 270EX external flash indoor pictures and portraits have improved a lot! Great combination: SX30IS and 270EX! And I have much still to learn with this camera and flash!Highly recommended!Every day I learn to use resources better camera, I am more convinced of the five stars that dot the SX30IS. The full manual mode, knowing how to use, delivers excellent photos. And the automatic mode or semi-automatic'm also learning what the correct situation in which it must be utilized. The effect of leaving only one color appearing in the picture and the remaining P&B; found it very interesting.

Reviews.Title: External flash hot shoe photography sub-par
Reviews.Author: JB
Reviews.Content: Camera ok but for two things:(1) I brought this camera to use one of my external flash units on it but every picture comes out underexposed no matter how you set the camera and/or the flash. Shoots ok with the built-in flash.(2) Inadvertently turns on if you accidently hit the poorly placed play button when taking the camera in and out of your pocket/bag etc.Other than that, pictures and video are quite good.Update: April 2013Disable all of the Auto-Safty stuff on the camera and it will behave like a proper camera.

Reviews.Title: Lots of BANG for your BUCK!!!
Reviews.Author: Steve
Reviews.Content: I did a lot or soul searching before buying this camera.  I considered going back to the full size EOS but, I found I didn't use a camera as much as I used too and I did not want to haul a lot of weight around when I wanted to use it.  This camera has a lot of features both for beginner and someone who has used cameras before. I guarentee if you get it you will like it.  It's light, not bulky, easy to use and has a lot of features.

Reviews.Title: More Than a Snapshot
Reviews.Author: Susie Cincinnati
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera several months ago to take on vacation.  I'm an average person with average photography skills., but I wanted a camera with a little more sophistication than my small 'point & shoot' camera. After extensive research I decided that this was the camera for me.  I was right!This camera has  a wide range of easy to use options.  The multiple picture choices (landscape, sports, portrait, etc)  are easy to use with the turn of a dial.  I took it boating & I used the 'sports' feature to capture friends jumping off a cliff! They were stunned when I got clear pictures of the fear on their faces in mid-air!  The zoom is super and produces clear photos, as if you were right next to your subject.  My vacation pictures were awesome! I was able to get intricate details of butterflies, flowers and sailboats  in the middle of Lake Erie.  My son was so impressed with this camera that he asked for one for his birthday.  We now have two of these Canons in the family!Even though I love the camera (I bought 2 of them after all!), there are a few things that I don't like.  The zoom feature is great, but it sometimes takes a couple of tries to get it where you want it and it doesn't adjust very smoothly.  This can be bothersome when you're trying to capture a picture 'in the moment'.  Also, sometimes I find that if i don;t hold the camera perfectly still it won't focus, most of the time it's fine.

Reviews.Title: Brilliant!
Reviews.Author: Lan
Reviews.Content: I love this digital camera, in fact, the quality can be compared with professional cameras! I think I made one of my best purchase ever. Also, the delivery is very fast.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: H. Potter "Oldhiker"
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera. I no longer need my DSLR for most pictures. I even got some excellent bird and mammal pictures with this little beauty. The 11" X 14" prints I had made are as good as the prints from the DSLR. It is simply amazing. To see a bunch of my pictures, look at this gallery:[...]

Reviews.Title: Love this camera!
Reviews.Author: Hidow
Reviews.Content: I have owned a Canon camera for many years and have always loved their products. 6 months ago I became in desperate need of a new camera and this is the one I found.  One of the things that caught my eye when reading reviews was that it can take pictures of the moon, and it DOES!I love all of the different options it comes with, I have yet to discover them all.  My previous Canon had a "super-macro" option and I do miss having it on this one.The ease of use is great. I have been at a dog show and have handed my camera to a friend that is not used to this size of a camera and they were able to get great photos for me.I really wish there was a hardcopy of the manual with the camera. Quite often if I am using it out in the field I dont have the ability to look things up.For the price it is a great all around camera, I have recommended it to several friends.

Reviews.Title: Great for wildlife photography!
Reviews.Author: Ireflyfish
Reviews.Content: This camera is perfect for my needs. I bought the SX30is for an upcoming trip to Alaska.  It is small enough not to feel bulky, but big enough to fit in your hand like a DSLR. It's very lightweight, which makes it easy to have around your neck for long periods without feeling like a brick. The controls are very intuitive, with more than enough menu/function options for the average amateur. The zoom is Amazing! The Image stabilization works great. This camera is a replacement for a Nikon Coolpix L120 I bought last month and returned because of the poor image stabilization. The Nikon's image stabilization was very shaky and hard to get used to. Canon got it right with it's IS.Cons: The zoom assist button is too close to where you naturally place your thumb, and sometimes gets accidentally depressed. The issue only compounds itself when operating the camera with gloves on. The zoom did lock-up on me once, but rebooting fixed it. The flash has to be manually raised in order to operate. Just something to get used to.Overall the Canon Sx30is is an exceptional camera for the money. It's a great amateur  wildlife photography camera.

Reviews.Title: Great for the price point
Reviews.Author: Online Shopper
Reviews.Content: I wanted a camera that would provide me with some DLR features, without the DLR price and hassle, and this camera does that.  The zoom and low light photo quality is amazing.  I don't think the photo quality is such that you could blow up a photo to much beyond a 8 by 10, but for hobby photography, it's a great camera.

Reviews.Title: canon with vision
Reviews.Author: Lynn E. Polk
Reviews.Content: decided to buy a new unit for the summer and this one caught my eye. I had purchased another canon with a 20x zoom and then was forced to return it for one reason or another.when I saw this camera, I decided to get it to replace the other and it is a good decision.  good canon quality and light carry, two ways to compose the shots and bright screens.

Reviews.Title: Great for amatures
Reviews.Author: K. Paige "BluesChick"
Reviews.Content: I'm not a camera person. I didn't know anything about photography until I purchased this camera. I wanted a DSLR but my husband talked me into this stepping stone before jumping in. I'm very happy I did.It's very easy to use. We have had Canon digital point and shoot cameras for a long time. I understood the basic functions. Basic as in make sure the dial is set to Auto. I got a few books out of the library on photography and was taking good pictures in no time.After figuring out the exposure meter on the LCD display (it's easy I just needed to take some baby steps), I was able to play with exposure and aperture to take pictures in any kind of light. There's also a low light program setting which comes in very handy. It's fun to play with the exposure at baseball games.I've enjoyed taking fisheye pictures of my dog. He's not as thrilled though. B&W; pictures come out very nice and there's also a sepia setting which was new and cool to me. We did the Kentucky Bourbon trail last summer. It was fun to play with the sepia and b&w; settings but insert one color such as red at the Maker's Mark distillery.The zoom is fantastic! I was able to get really great pictures of the Statue of Liberty from the Empire State Building. I've never been able to even see any detail with other cameras I've had. This one makes it look like we're in Battery Park taking pictures. I took some pictures of the moon using a tripod. I was overly impressed. The zoom should be a real selling point for this camera.Overall I'm very impressed with the pictures I've taken being a novice with a fancy camera. Maybe someday I'll take the leap to DSLR. But for now I'm very happy with the super zoom.

Reviews.Title: Great 'All-In-One' Package
Reviews.Author: Mary Mintz "onthebeam"
Reviews.Content: Ordered this for sons' graduation gift and are both VERY pleased. Is true what others say about 'low light' pictures being outstanding along with all other credited attributes. True, the view screen is a 'bit' grainy, but who cares over such a minor problem when EVERYTHING else is spectacular for the value? When reviewing pics, they are crystal clear, just like they turn out:) Movies and sound included! All other reviews I've read on extended zoom camera packages have at least one or two major problems concerning: either/or movies, sound, pictures, flash, hand-ability, and ease of use. Yeah, Canon!

Reviews.Title: Nice camera you wont be disappointed
Reviews.Author: Alisha
Reviews.Content: This camera takes great pictures and I love the zoom on it. I am able to get nice shots and videos even from far away. It has been great for the kids concerts too because you can adjust the viewer to still see what you are recording. This is if you have to hold the camera over your head to get around that tall person sitting in front of you! :) I am not at all tech savvy, but this camera is a point and shoot so it is easy to learn. It has great battery life. It has a rechargeable battery, my old camera ate through batteries like crazy but this one I haven't had to charge since Christmas!

Reviews.Title: nice camera with some important flaws
Reviews.Author: JulianL.
Reviews.Content: Excellent camera! I really loved it! Pictures are amazing with this camera, and zoom is out of this world!! Video recording is Full HD and as always, Canon gives you an excellent product! BUT, I had to return it because on lens flaws. When lens is out in zoom, no matter how close or far the object is, it tends to shut down the camera because of a lens error. That happened to me every single time I used at least a little bit of zoom, or trying to use micro, or trying to focus lens. It was very frustrating since sometimes one shot can't get repeated. I had to return it to Amazon... Overall, it's an excellent camera with very high potential.

Reviews.Title: BEST CAMERA I EVER BOUGHT
Reviews.Author: lgch
Reviews.Content: After checking out several cameras, I decided to get this Canon one and I couldn't be happier with my decision. I love my camera; it is probably the best thing I bought this year. The picture quality is excellent and the camera itself is really impressive with all the options and features that offers (my favorite feature is when the camera takes a picture automatically when someone smiles, it is awesomeee!!) If you are looking for a camera that can take professional pictures but don't want to spend more than 400$, I would suggest you get this one. It is worth it!

Reviews.Title: only a few difficulties with Canon camera
Reviews.Author: Jamie P
Reviews.Content: The only problems I have are:There is no book. There is a CD, so I have to have my computer nearby if I want to look up something about the camera.I sometimes turn off the camera when I mean to press the shutter button (it is close to the power button).I often press playback when I am setting up for a shot. Again, button in a bad place.I don't know how to use it in low light. (No book with me when I'm trying to figure it out).The movie setting only takes pictures, until you take a wild guess and press the red button.After taking a picture, it takes a full 1-2 seconds to get the screen back to see what the next picture will be. Frustrating when taking several pics of a moving event.I like that I can zoom during videoing.

Reviews.Title: Canon SX30IS
Reviews.Author: Sohail Assi
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. It has everything you will need without getting the expensive bulky cameras. Macro photos is a little challenge but other than that, it is perfect and for the price, it is a bargain. I highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Good for wildlife photography
Reviews.Author: Scubadore
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera so I could take pictures of wildlife while kayaking.  So far I have gotten some great photos of subjects that would have been too far away for other cameras.  Although I agree with other reviewers that the picture quality may be lower than other cameras, the image stabilization and high power zoom make it perfect for my needs.

Reviews.Title: Can SX301S
Reviews.Author: mdvv
Reviews.Content: Canon SX30IS 14.1MP Digital Camera with 35x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 2.7 Inch Wide LCDOnly being the 'family' photographer this product was a great investment.  It allows you to get up close and personal to your subject matter from such a long way away, it was like having the subject matter right in front of you especially seeing you didn't need the hassel of carrying around extra lens.I looked around prior to purchasing the camera and I feel that this one gave valve for money.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: DJDCK4
Reviews.Content: I did alot of research before picking this camera.  I love the zoom, at full zoom looks like you are right next to the object.  My favorite feature however is the flip out lcd screen.  My husband and I take trips alone and this lets me take pics of us together and center with the background.  I can also take pics of myself.  Love it!!!

Reviews.Title: Not happy
Reviews.Author: Tim Alberry
Reviews.Content: I have only ever used Canon digital camera's.  I used my Canon S5 all the time and got great pictures out of it in most situations.  I know the limits of point and shoot cameras so I didn't expect the world from the S5.  I wanted and upgrade and saw the SX30 IS.  I still didn't expect the world from it either, but I do have some expectations.The SX30 IS takes good pictures from an extreme lens, and 35x is surely as extreme as it gets.  When you have one lens to cover that large of a range in a point and shoot, you can't expect SLR quality.  My problem is, past about halfway zoomed out, I started getting a lot of vignetting in the top corners.  And it's weird, because the top left corner doesn't do it as bad as the top right corner and I don't notice it in the bottom corners.  If I can't zoom out more than halfway without cropping off the top section of the photo, what good is the rest of the zoom range?  This is even worse when you try to stitch photos together and the top right corner is shadowed and the top left corner of the next photo is quite a bit brighter.I have owned 10 Canon digital cameras, from cheap point and shoot up to the Digital Rebel Xsi.  I have only been unhappy with two and this was far more disappointing as it was significantly more expensive than the A570 that overexposed everything.  I hope Canon quality isn't going down but I am definitley considering Nikon and others for future purchases now.

Reviews.Title: Doesn't weigh as much as it says!
Reviews.Author: B. Daniels
Reviews.Content: Ignore the "Product Details" page where it says this camera weighs 21.2 pounds.  Unless Amazon is selling some special heavy-weight version, it really doesn't weigh that much!On a serious note, the SX30IS is a fantastic camera with all the bells and whistles you could want outside of a DSLR camera.  Great zoom feature, fantastic video recording, and the automation of the camera is very intuitive.

Reviews.Title: Canon SX30IS Performs Well
Reviews.Author: D J POSNER
Reviews.Content: Canon has done it again, perfected a great, lightweight camera that is user friendly for an amateur yet provides a depth of options for a serious photographer.  The shutter button is a bit cumbersome and its placement takes some getting used to, but the digital images that are produced by this terrific camera is worth the effort of balancing the camera in your hand.

Reviews.Title: The best buy!!
Reviews.Author: Marcia F. Kaye
Reviews.Content: So so happy with this purchase! I love my camera, I take it everywhere, friends are amazed with the quality of my pictures. I am not a professional photographer, I am still learning some things this camera can do but so far I am thrilled.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Sswain918
Reviews.Content: This camera is everything a beginning photographer could want. It zooms in as far as it would with other cameras with an extra lens. It has multiple settings, the screen flips around for excellent camera-whoring duck-face moments, and is neither too small or too big, so I don't feel like a dorky dad taking pictures of his kids in Disneyland.

Reviews.Title: great camera for the money
Reviews.Author: coco55
Reviews.Content: I am a amateur photographer, but this camera make taking great pictures very easy. The zoom feature is great when used with a tripod on higher levels of zoom. Battery life is great, great buy.

Reviews.Title: A nice and good camera
Reviews.Author: Wilmer Saldivia
Reviews.Content: Before I bought this camera, I checked on the net a lot of reviews. Well, many of the reviews were right about the pros and cons of this camera. It's not for beginners or people looking for a point-and-shout camera. I used almost all the time in manual mode. And the pics are just great! Of course, between the possibilities. I love to take landscape pics, or in situations were a very good zoom is needed. For low light or very simple pics I use a pocket sized Nikon.So, check the reviews, learn about the pros and cons and take your choice. I did it, and I'm very happy.Edited 03-14-2013.I still enjoy this camera! Purchased a tripod, learn some tips and play a lot with CHDK. From long exposure pics to long interval shoots. Amazing! Maybe you can find a better camera than this one, but the SX30is fills all my needs.

Reviews.Title: My experience with the SX30is
Reviews.Author: Iman
Reviews.Content: I've owned this canon for a year now, and I FINALLY got to figure out how to work all the features on it and increase the quality and such.At first I was very disappointed with the blurry and pixely quality but then I realized that my ISO was too high, now I am an amateur photographer who's practicing her photography skills really hard.the zoom on this camera is great! & so is the video quality!... I've thought about buying the canon rebel instead but Im so glad I didnt, I might buy some filters and extra lenses for it to see the quality change.Now, this camera is great! It has all the features you need but as some of the reviewers have said before me, you might find some difficulties with the indoor shooting. You just need to make sure you have enough light around you.

Reviews.Title: Has some flaws.
Reviews.Author: Brent Finnigan
Reviews.Content: Overall this is an OK camera that has a very powerful zoom and easy to operate.  The video quality is good but you will need conversion software to play or upload it to your PC. However after using it for 4 months there are some very annoying flaws.  In moderate low light it won't focus real well.  It will also take pics that will have a "painted" fusion of color with no detail.  Much like a color overexposure.Most annoying is the zoom is very slow responding and sometime won't zoom until you take a pic and it resets.  It will also be zoomed out and it will auto zoom back in.  It ends up being a tug-o-war and I have missed many pics because of that flaw.  The auto focus while zoomed is not real good and 50% of the time it will be out of focus.  The manual focus is completely worthless since it's done with the tiny rotary wheel on the back.  It takes forever and the LCD won't let you get a good read on how crisp it is.I have owned several of the smaller Canon Powershots and they have been great overall cameras.  And I am going back to using my SX120 IS 12 MP more often.  Save your money and go for the EOS series or go with the compact Suppershot and Powershot series.  I have read that Canon uses their 12 MP chip and tweaks the software to get it to 14 MP.  That may be a part of the color and low light problems it has.

Reviews.Title: Does it all
Reviews.Author: By Chance
Reviews.Content: This is an easy camera to use with all the bells and whistles.  Great telephoto lens without the hassle of a big long lens.  We can take pictures 1/2 mile away as if the subjects were right in front of us.  Clear shots.  Lots of options for the creative photographer as well as presets for the beginner.

Reviews.Title: my first camera
Reviews.Author: ttdiva
Reviews.Content: i shopped\researched meticulously prior to this purchase. I am an mom of three who needed to get some pictures before my babies are all grown. This camera does way more than i bargained for. The pictures are crisp and clear and the videos are also fabulous. the most interesting though is the  battery life. I charged mine fully once. It is still going strong after, 4 concerts, 6 diners, endless church functions and the whole christmas season. Lets just say I have no regrets with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: Canon Powershot sx30 IS
Reviews.Author: gmarin
Reviews.Content: Canon PowerShot SX30 IS isthe best PowerShot of the series so far.  I had a S3 IS before, and even smaller onces in the past, all with zoom and image stabilizers, which I really liked.  But the sx30 IS is really a step up with the double of pixels and an even greater zoom (35x instead of 12x).  A fine piece of equipment!

Reviews.Title: Bad to the Bone!
Reviews.Author: Moon)Dawg "Moon)Dawg"
Reviews.Content: This camera replaced a old Kodak that died after nearly 200,000 photos. I kept reading reviews about cameras and really didn't get a lot of good information so I went to my friends who like me really hammer a camera and found that they were mainly using two brands and Canon was the most popular.I am by no means a professional nor do I pretend to be but I take a lot of pictures and a very short span of time, 500 to 700 a day on weekends and then spend all week processing them. Shooting at a Renaissance Festival is a brutal environment for both camera and photographer with shifting light, shifting targets and constant movement in the background and add the fact that I like to shoot with a beer in one hand and a camera in the other.I am still learning how to use this magical piece of equipment but have it mostly dialed in now after 3000 plus shots and it has performed most gracefully under extreme pressure thus far. The video is most excellent as well and I have taken several using only a class 4 chip successfully and the zoom works smoothly in both video and normal mode. If you do purchase one of these I hope you enjoy it as much as I do and I pray that it has as long a life as the old friend it replacesNamaste - Moon)Dawg

Reviews.Title: AWESOME!
Reviews.Author: Felly26
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera last week and just got it today and I LOVE it. It takes great pictures and the zoom is Amazing. It's the best camera I have ever owned my last one was an olympus I don't know the model but it was nothing compared to THIS. It is slow when doing continuous shooting but that doesn't matter to me as long as I can get good pictures which I can. Love this Camera and would definately Recommend this to a friend. Great camera no complaints.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Russel R. Maschek Sr. "RRM"
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera to replace an old one, was a great decision. It's easy to use, if you take the time to go throught the menu and take your time with the first pictures you take. After that it's just great memories made easy. I would reccomend it to a friend.

Reviews.Title: Canon SX30IS
Reviews.Author: KsTinMan
Reviews.Content: I have owned Point & Shoot cameras since the Sony Mavica days. I owned a good Pentax SLR before digital cameras hit the market. The Canon SX30IS is more like a D-SLR than it is a P&S.; I have a lot of learning to do. So far I still shoot better photos with my old Sony DSC-W5, but I'm sure that is my own ineptitude. I'll add more once I get through this 200 page PDF file that is the excuse for a manual. I have to agree with other reviewers on this one. I don't have a computer with me when I'm out taking pictures, so the PDF manual is useless in that regard.Well, it's been three months since I purchased the Canon SX30 IS camera. I'm not very pleased, to put it as nicely as possible. I'll leave my true feelings out of the review and do my best to present the facts without adding negatively biased opinions.When I purchased this camera, the intent was to get photos of wild animals. A few good examples would be a Bald Eagle in flight or a goose making a water landing.I have not yet been able to get even one single sharply focused picture when I have the Optical zoom set towards the higher end (say 20X to 35X). I have tried setting all possible Auto-Focus options to every position in an attempt to get the camera to focus clearly. I also use a tripod, and have the self-timer set to two seconds. The camera is stable and untouched when the shutter fires, however the subject of my picture is still slightly blurred. Even when the subject is inanimate and stationary. Pretty poor performance.I have contacted Canon support and read all of the knowledge base articles concerning focus. There is no help there (that is not already in in the mega-manual), and none of it gave me any sharply focused photographs when I tried the ideas they had. I have a trouble ticket (which I wrote today) in with Canon now to see if it's possible that I've missed something. If so, I'm a lot dumber than I thought I was. I've spent the last three months trying different options and settings.Bottom line: I'm going to take the loss and return this camera. It takes great portraits, but I can get a much less expensive point-and-shoot for that. The lesson learned? I will never buy a camera without having first used it in a retail store so I know for sure that I am not wasting my money. DO NOT BUY THIS CAMERA!!!

Reviews.Title: Photography for Dummies
Reviews.Author: anon
Reviews.Content: I'm definitely not a photographer, but no one would know the difference.  Takes great pictures!  Not a big deal, but I wish I'd have known the camera doesn't come with a memory disk. Love the zoom!!!

Reviews.Title: LOVE THIS CAMERA!!!
Reviews.Author: Wendy
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. This is an upgrade from A620 which I absolutely loved. this camera takes great pictures. The suto focus is a bit annoying at times but it wakes great pictures. The only downfall is that is a bit clunky and heavy but its not unbearable.

Reviews.Title: Great camera at this price
Reviews.Author: Wendy
Reviews.Content: I love this camera.  It gives you a lot of creative control and very good image quality.  At most time, I used the manual mode setting the sharpness and contrast to the highest.  The picture is crisp clear and sharp.  I liked the super zoom of lense very much.  You can take a close-up picture from 100 feet away.  The image stabilizing system is good too.  I can take pretty good pictures with lens fully zoomed and visible shaking of the camera.  This is hard to achieve even with SLR camera. I would say that this camera is not good for point-and-shoot and fast action.  Other than that, it is excellent camera overall.

Reviews.Title: More bang for the buck!!!
Reviews.Author: lloyd rocks
Reviews.Content: My wife and I bought this camera for our daughter's field trip. We were so happy with the results we got... the wide angle lens was great for taking group shots, ensuring everybody is "in" the picture as well as landscape shots while telephoto is also okay for taking portraits. Though not in the SLR speed range, this camera is great for travel and very practical. Overall, we think this is a very good camera for the family. We bought ours just recently, so we are still trying to master all its useful functions....for its price and Canon expertise...this is really a lot of bang for the buck!!!!

Reviews.Title: New Camera
Reviews.Author: kathyd2011
Reviews.Content: I love the camera so far, still learning how to use all the features.It's different from all the Kodak cameras that I used, but I'm sure I will learn as time goes by. My brother who takes excellent pictures recommended this one...

Reviews.Title: Good value for money
Reviews.Author: Jay
Reviews.Content: Had purchased this to be gifted so tested it for a small time and everything works and is good for a camera between point and shoot and DSLR features

Reviews.Title: A Must Have
Reviews.Author: Gilbert Grape
Reviews.Content: Its light in weight. The screen rotates 180 degrees making it easy take pictures. If you have the screen open and have the screen pointing up it will change the picture to fit in the screen. The zoom is only stable when you hit 35x and even then sometimes its unstable. You can go all the way up to 140x if your willing to be patient. The battery compartment is very easy to put the battery in. It includes a user guide on a cd which if you don't have a computer can be frustrating. The lens will go back into the camera after a minute but you can change that in the menu. I recommend using Transcend 16GB Class 10 SDHC Card (TS16GSDHC10)as it works well with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Canon SX301S
Reviews.Author: Olger R. Duran "olri59"
Reviews.Content: Light camera good rice and easy to use. I checked many cameras before I got this. This one has an easy record botton that makes the filming quick and easy.

Reviews.Title: WOW
Reviews.Author: Gross "Mark"
Reviews.Content: I got this camera to help me with my product catalog, And all I can say is that I'm thankful I got it.It is amazing, easy to learn and the pictures are amazing Sharp and clear,U use it now for my catalog and for my family as well,I highly recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding !!
Reviews.Author: Christine M. Rutkowski "CRNA"
Reviews.Content: Purchased for my daughter who needed a new camera. She didn't want anything bulky or difficult to use. This camera fit the bill to a T.. Light weight: she can handle her twin sons and shoot one handed.... and it's super easy..Great pictures are forthcoming !

Reviews.Title: Superb !
Reviews.Author: Sunil Vyas
Reviews.Content: I love this Camera and also got good deal from Amazon. This has amazing picture quality and ZOOM In feature. The only concern is, while I am zooming becuase it has big lense with extra zoom features, it make little noise (like shutter) when it stops and also lost vision for a while.Other than that this is the best product so far I have observed as I spend lot of time to find similar Camera in this category and finally concluded that this is what I really looking for. Nice & crispy Picture Quality (In Door and Out Door).Love This. !

Reviews.Title: Nice little camera for the price!
Reviews.Author: Jean
Reviews.Content: My husband has a D-40 Nikon and loves it but wanted a camera user friendly.I love the point and shoot with the ability to zoom out.On our trip out west i was able to take pictures one minute--then take movies.Great little camera for me to operate.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: momoftwinsies
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera for over a year, and I still love it just as much as when I bought it! Its obviously not a DSLR camera, and comparing it to one is unfair. However, it does have a manual mode, and you can play with the settings if you have an interest in manual photography, but don't want to spend a few grand to find out if its your cup of tea. I LOVE the viewing screen, you can have it facing in while not in use to protect it, turn it to face out like your standard digital camera, or turn it so that you can see the screen from the front side of the camera (screen facing front happens to be my toddlers' favorite way to have their picture taken!) or you can tilt it and angle it if you are shooting overhead. Having a screen that tilts down was great at my son's Christmas program, so I could hold the camera overhead and get good shots. I can't say enough about how great this camera is!

Reviews.Title: Outstanding "point and shoot" camera
Reviews.Author: WX Guesser
Reviews.Content: At one time (before it got stolen) I had an Olympus OM2 camera with a wide angle/macro lens, 51mm 1.4 lens and a 200mm lens. Total cost (late `70's) over $1500. The SX30IS does everything that my Olympus did and much more. It will take pictures in candle light, and zoom to 850mm (SLR equivalent).  One thing that those who complain about the picture quality at full zoomed forget is that at anything greater than a 200mm zoom (SLR equivalent) you MUST use a tripod. The controls for manual exposure make this as easy to to manually set shutter speed and aperture as any DSLR.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for those who don't have time and money to learn DSLR
Reviews.Author: Book Worm "Philip"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for my road trip to Seattle and Vancouver recently.The reason of purchasing this camera is (1) I don't have time to learn to use DSLR. If I cannot explore the best feature of DSLR, it will not do me any good. This camera has all the features I want. (2) If I don't have to learn to use DSLR, there is no point to spend almost $1,000 for a decent DSLR.Most of my photos were taken in good light condition and the quality of those photos were excellent. For the photos in poor light condition, the flash light help. Also, without a manual, it is easy to figure out the settings of the camera after a few tries.There are something that I want to complain about this camera though:1. I wish that Canon can have automatic cover for the lens just like other PowerShot series camera. Sometimes it is a little bit annoying to remove the cover when you see something you want to capture and it is passing by.2. There is a button right below the on-off button which automatically set the camera to the scene and surrounding condition. If you accidentally press this button, it will automatically adjust the zoom and other settings and you cannot change it. I did not realize it until this happened three to four times.3. The battery runs out fast. It requires recharge about every 300 - 350 photos. So, it is better to take extra battery if you are on a road trip.I think it is wrong to compare this camera with DSLR camera. They are different types of cameras. I won't expect it to perform as well as a DSLR camera. I have to say that in order to get the best out of a camera (any camera), some basic knowledge and techniques of photography should be needed. We cannot blame the poor photo quality because we shoot pictures randomly in all condition.

Reviews.Title: The one you should buy before you get into DSLR
Reviews.Author: TheLibertine
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera for three weeks now and I love it. The zoom is fantastic, it shoots great pictures at high shutter speeds, it is very easy to use but has plenty of settings for the more experienced photographers. The only problem I have with this camera is that pictures at 800 ISO or higher are not good, there's lots of noise. If portability is not an issue for you, and want to shoot decent HD video and great bright picture then this is the camera for you.

Reviews.Title: best camera in its class!
Reviews.Author: residae
Reviews.Content: I love this camera! This is my third in the Canon S IS series...I had the S3 IS, then the S5 IS and now this.  AWESOME. Love the video quality and all the features (tilt shift, selective color, fisheye, etc.) And the ZOOM. }et me tell ya, this thing has ZOOM. I recently took this to Disneyland as my backup/video and I was not disappointed!

Reviews.Title: Very good camera
Reviews.Author: Sara
Reviews.Content: I am very happy with this camera.  It is not dificult to use and it has great features:  image stabilization, zoom, lens, etc. that makes this camera a very good option for any person that loves to take all type of photographs.

Reviews.Title: SX30IS
Reviews.Author: Lw Bushrod "VA Bass Playa"
Reviews.Content: Order shipped earlier than predicted and arrived in perfect condition. Camera is very easy to operate without reading manual. Manual has been easy to manipulate so far although I have not looked at all the features. Camera takes very good pics at a high quality. I am totally satisfied with product so far.

Reviews.Title: My wife loves her new camera
Reviews.Author: jread
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my wife for Christmas and she loves it.  The only thing is the shutter speed isn't as fast as I would of hoped.  However, I don't know much about cameras and I just don't know how to operate it.  My sister inlaw has taken classes on cameras and such not and highly recommended this camera!  So far we have had it for about 3 weeks and love it.  It takes great pictures and we went to the MSU vs Michigan Gator Bowl last week (Go Dawgs!!! 52-14) and got some great pictures of the players and coaches about 75 to 100 yards away.  The zoom is incrediable.  Some michigan fans were sitting in front of us and had one of those $1,000 interchangable lens.  His pictures and zoom were just as good as ours.  For the money this has to be the best camera you can get, if your not a professional photographer.  If your wanting great photos of family and events and don't want to pay high dollar for the professional cameras this has to be best one!  I had the owner of my home town's newspaper tell me this is the best of the nonprofessional cameras!Great Buy!

Reviews.Title: GOOD CAMERA.
Reviews.Author: A. C. Lima "NAGUAL MD"
Reviews.Content: AS FAR AS MEGAZOOM CAMERAS ARE CONCERNED.,THE BEST IS YET TO COME.THIS CAMERA HAS:PROS:1-LIGTH AND COMPACT.2-WIDE ANGLE AT ZERO SETTING.3-GOOD PRICE.4-NICE CAMERA TO CARRY ON TRIPS.CONS:1-IMAGE QUALITY JUST REGULAR.2-CHEAPLY BUILT.3-ZOOM LEVER HAS DELAY PROBLEMS IN LENS ACTIVATING.4-IT REALLY IS NOT A 35X ZOOM- AT BEST 28X.

Reviews.Title: color saturation
Reviews.Author: lico43
Reviews.Content: I upgrade from Canon A620 that was working very well, to Canon sx30is.I am very happy with the camera, I had it since 3 weeks ago a had taken aprox. 300 photos, all came very nice. The only thing that I dislike a little is the size of the camera, compare to my old A620.What I like the most is the telephoto x35, I took pictures from a volcano top 50 kms+ away, where some antenas are located, and the antenas came out very nice. I am very happy of this.I do recommend the camera.

Reviews.Title: Great out of the box.
Reviews.Author: Got boost?
Reviews.Content: I have owned a couple of Canon digital cameras so I was somewhat familiar with the menus and most controls, but even a first owner should have little trouble operating this camera.  I'll read the manual in the future if I want to get more creative with the camera.My only dislike is the proprietary battery pack, impossible to use fresh batteries in a pinch.  On the other hand I've taken over 100 pics over a few days on a single charge and there is plenty of power left according to the indicator.In my opinion this camera is easy to use, takes great pics, almost a digital SLR at a much better price, especially taking into account the fantastic zoom.  Good deal for a photo dummy like me.Can't comment on its video capabilities as I have not yet used it.

Reviews.Title: Best camera ever...!!!
Reviews.Author: andres
Reviews.Content: I had the panasonic FZ35 before, and let me tell you, the diference is between heaven and earth,  The colors in the Canon SX30IS are more brilliant and the definition is 100% better...the only issue is a little over contrast on the pictures but still the best, Im not a pro. but definitely Canon is Canon..!!!

Reviews.Title: Canon SX30IS Poor Man's Digital SLR with Zoom
Reviews.Author: Terry Clinard
Reviews.Content: Canon SX30IS 14.1MP Digital Camera with 35x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 2.7 Inch Wide LCD  I have been an Amateur Astronomer for over 42 years and I have nothing but praise for this Zoom camera.  It is simple to use and takes excellent pictures for what it is designed to do.  Low light is very good. Picture quality is also superb.  On terrestial objects, with & without the ZOOM function, the photos are pristine.  The optical quality of the lens system is much more then I expected, even using the maximunm magnification of 140 power.  I will post 2 photos on the "customer input view & share images".  If Canon would consider changing the shutter open function to greater then 15 seconds to always on, then it has the potential to be used as an CCD imaging camera for various levels of Astro Photography.

Reviews.Title: WOW
Reviews.Author: Wolfhere
Reviews.Content: I admit it. I am an amateur. I bought the Canon Powershot SX10 IS a couple years ago and that camera has a 20x zoom. I still get great pictures from it.Now to the Canon Powershot SX30 IS with 35X zoom. You would think that zooming out to 840mm would be a little shaky and images blurred. This is not necessarily the case. Stabilization is awesome (I still have to tuck the elbows and cradle with the left). I have been able to take VERY good shots right out of the box. Great P&S; (point and shoot) camera, just like it's grandpa. There is a little problem with Depth of Field, even in manual mode, f8 is all you can do to decrease DOF. No lenses to lug around, and all the modes needed for most situations.I have tried the Fuji Finepix HS10. NOT a P&S; camera. The zoom is all manual (in comparison to the power-zoom of the Canon SX30IS)and stabilization was almost non-existent, no matter what the zoom. In auto mode, I got 5 pics out of 60. I returned the camera, but would recommend to the professional photographer. My new Canon Powershot SX30 IS, my test results were exactly the opposite. 55 out of 60 under the same conditions (ie. Sequim Bay, winter, high tide...etc.)and the failures from not taking my time on the zoom.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Câmera
Reviews.Author: Eliseu
Reviews.Content: I had a Canon Powershot S1, a S5, a SX10 and now upgraded to a SX30. Each one surprised me, but this last model is really amazing. The IS is extremally efficient, the image quality is superb despíte the increase of Mpixels without change the sensor digic4. The only thing I needed to use two or three times to familiarize was the decreasing size of Viewfinder lcd. Although this... I'm pretty happy with my last upgrade.

Reviews.Title: Pro results--point 'n shoot ease
Reviews.Author: Nameless Guy "Georgia actor"
Reviews.Content: The title says it:The 35X zoom gives you professional flexibility and choices without having to change lenses.  Starting with a nice wide angle lens is an option that's been missing in Digital Zooms, and it's a nice option to have.I transitioned from a 5MP Canon Powershot and found the learning curve was easy.Yet it's as easy to use as my wife's point n' shoot.CONS:  I wish manufacturers of digi cameras which can also shoot video would make the zoom function silent.  This COULD be a serious video camera if the zoom didn't sound like a garbage truck backing up.All in all, there's an awful lot to like.  Huge bang for the buck.  Hope this is helpful.

Reviews.Title: So much potential
Reviews.Author: W. Joo
Reviews.Content: I had hoped this camera would complement my 50D as a super-zoom for outdoor shooting.  The lens range on this camera is amazing.  I wish the photos were better...especially in marginal (overcast sky) lighting...surprisingly grainy.  I've had this camera for about a month and found the following flaws too hard to live with:- Camera is somewhat hard to hold and some buttons are encumbered by the neck strap.- No thread for filters...you have to buy an adapter.- No remote control capability...I've not been able to find any such feature.- Slow response time between shots.- Does not produce 1080p video.- CCD based...good for video but poor low light performance.The differences in the 14+ Mpixel images between the SX30IS and the 50D are way too significant.  I was hoping image quality would be somewhat close; thus, mixing similar photos between the cameras would result in marginal differences.  I hope Canon fixes these problems in the next SX release.  Again, the range of the lens is absolutely amazing.UPDATE:I took three cameras (all Canons...50D, SD940IS and SX30IS) to Italy and compared results.  My tiny SD940IS worked wonders in all modes to include Auto...not true for SX30IS...great results all around for the 50D. In fact, the SD940IS performed incredibly well in low light conditions. Indoor photos taken inside the Duomo (cathedral next to the Leaning Tower of Pisa) on a snowy overcast day produced results on SD940IS that almost kept up with my 50D. The SX30IS' photos were darker, grainy and somewhat blurry. I tested the SX30IS and SD940IS in both  Auto and P modes...great results almost all the time on SD940IS; not true for SX30IS.  The SX30IS auto mode couldn't find a consistent shooting mode and were confused by the faces found on the statues and frescoes.  I'm dropping the rating to 2 stars (from 3).  If the zoom range wasn't there then I'd give it just 1 star.BTW, another missing feature: GPS.  The camera is pretty bulky; thus, I'm sure Canon could have included a small GPS receiver.  In fact, carrying this camera was almost as much a challenge as carrying my SLR.  In fact, this camera takes up almost all the space inside my Canon Rebel XTi case...surprisingly large.One final note: I've been a Canon fan for some 25 years now.  This camera along with the T80 were the only disappointing Canons I've purchased over the years.

Reviews.Title: Not a "point and shot", Not for Beginers
Reviews.Author: Elio R. Millan C "Elio R"
Reviews.Content: This camera is not a "point and shot" cameraNo es una camara "apunta y dispara"Not for beginers.No es para principiantes.If you want take "good quality" pictures at better resolution, you must have some experience setting ISO, Aperture, Shutter speed, level of flash and white balance, in manual mode, P mode, Av mode or Tv mode (read the manual first!!). Other way, you can take pictures in "amateur quality" in Auto mode.
